speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources
speechtext: It was a great opening.

Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I will do it again if you wish.
These changes which have been introduced will simplify and shorten the corporate income tax form, will reduce the cost of tax compliance for small businesses, will increase access to tax savings for growing small businesses and will reduce by over two-thirds the amount of the legislation relating to the low tax rate for small business. As we have been told, this is accomplished by the elimination of the accumulated deduction account which limited access of the small business tax rate to $1 million of accumulated income. As well, this is accomplished by the repeal of the provisions concerning non-qualifying business; namely, the professional practices of accountants, dentists, lawyers and medical doctors. I beg to differ with the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap by stressing that among these professions are a number of substantial individual investors in our economy. Further, these objectives are accomplished by simplifying the provisions affecting personal services businesses, specified investment businesses and corporate partnerships.
The oil and gas industry, which should be the major engine of our economic recovery, will be pleased, I believe, by the
retroactive relief rather than the retroactive penalty involved in the provisions which offer relief to a taxpayer who, after 1983, disposed of property or supply services that qualified for earned depletion. As well, there is some measure of reliability and predictability in the scheduled modification of law treating expenditures made for wells after 1983 as development expenses rather than exploration expenses, thereby having the deduction from 100 per cent to 30 per cent postponed for two years to January 1, 1986.
The primary producers of our country are looked after and their needs are addressed by the tax assistance to farmers, with the farm capital gain rollover up to $120,000 of taxable gain on the sale of qualifying property now being deductible if invested in an RRSP, and the transfer of family farms from one generation to another has now been facilitated. The meaning of a child of a taxpayer has been extended and family farm bequests and inheritances are put on the same basis as inter vivos transfers.
As well, Mr. Speaker, I applaud the initiatives taken in the personal income tax field with the ability to deduct moving expenses extended. There are a great many people in our nation today who, through no fault of their own, have been dislocated from their employment, whether by early retirement or by lay-off. Clause 62 of the Bill will provide a deduction for the qualifying moving expenses of an individual who moves to a new location in Canada in order to take up employment or start a business. Under the present law, in order to qualify for that deduction the taxpayer must have ceased before the move to carry on a business, to be employed at another location in Canada, or to be a full-time student at a post-secondary educational institution. This amendment eliminates the requirements relating to the taxpayer's occupation before he moves. As a result, the amendment ensures that an individual who is unemployed immediately before such a move will be entitled to claim a deduction for moving expenses. The amendment is applicable to relocations which occur after 1983.
There is a bias in these amendments which is in favour of the great middle class of Canada-investors, entrepreneurs and those who care about the revival of the economy in Canada. I believe there is an all-Party consensus that small business will be the major generator of employment in the foreseeable future. I applaud the Minister for her initiatives and the attendant humanity, simplicity, efficiency and predictability that goes with the amendments. They are small steps in the right direction, but in them we see some measures for the freeing of enterprise and the reinforcement of the sense of confidence which is present in Canada today.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Questions and comments? The Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis).

Mr. Speaker, I appreciated the comments of the Hon. Member and I look forward to his participation in this debate.
November 26, 1984

In his opening statements he referred to the banks. I would like to ask him, first, what are his views with respect to a tax system which permitted one of the largest banks in the world, namely the Royal Bank of Canada, to operate in 1982, when most Canadians were experiencing extreme economic and financial difficulties, in a tax regime where absolutely no income tax was paid and millions and millions of dollars were deferred to the 1983 tax year? I would like to hear his views on a tax system which permits that.

Mr. Speaker, I believe the subject of this debate is primarily the subject of small business simplification, relief for farmers, personal tax, et cetera. However, the subject was raised previously by the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap and, therefore, I will endeavour to answer the question.
Frankly, I do not think very much of a system which permits a major corporation not to pay tax-if the Hon. Member has his facts correct, and I will give him the benefit of the doubt. I think it is a declared policy of this Government that everyone will pay a reasonable share of tax. Of course, that includes corporations as well as individuals.

Mr. Speaker, the Hon. Member referred to an important part of the Bill, assistance to small business. He has identified, and rightly so that it is a critical sector in terms of creating jobs in the country in future years. He was also correct in saying that it was this sector which should be encouraged.
While this provision will take a significant amount of red tape out of the hands of the small entrepreneur and the small business person, would it not be much more advantageous for that individual, in terms of being able to expand and develop as a small-scale business, if the Government were to take action and significantly reduce interest rates?
Mr. Speaker, I am of the view that the more free the market, the better.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: On a further question, the Hon. Member for Algoma (Mr. Foster).

Mr. Speaker, when the Hon. Member gave his speech this morning it sounded as though this Bill was originally proposed by the Progressive Conservative Government. In fact, the Bill which is before the House is part of the Budget which was brought down by Mr. Lalonde last April 19. A number of changes were made to the tax system at that time, many of which the Tories castigated during the election campaign. Matters such as reducing the threshold for senior citizens who are required to pay quarterly tax, in order that they will no longer be required to pay income tax on a quarterly basis. In addition, the removal of the cumulative index for low-income tax levels in small business. That would reduce the amount of paperwork and taxes for small business by over $100 million a year. The Hon. Member mentioned that it favoured the largest sector of the income scale. It includes approximately 300,000 small business people.
Income Tax Act
I simply wanted to be clear as to whether the Hon. Member was aware that the proposals in Bill C-7 originated from the Budget which was brought down last spring and did not come from the Economic statement of the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson). That statement put forward practically nothing for small business, except that the proposals of the previous Liberal Government would be implemented. Perhaps the Hon. Member could clarify whether he is aware that the beneficial provisions of the Bill came from the Budget of last spring.

Mr. Speaker, 1 thought that I had given proper credit to the original initiative when I remarked that neither the Government Party nor the Official Opposition held a monopoly on wisdom or genius.
I believe that even the principles of the prodigal may be embraced when they are uttered as a last gasp of deathbed repentance. We recognized the marvellous improvement in Mr. Lalonde in his latter days.

Mr. Speaker, I have a further question for the Hon. Member. He referred to the elimination of the cumulative deduction account, which is certainly a wise move. Would he be able to venture an explanation as to why this special consideration was extended to certain selected professional groups, such as doctors, lawyers and accountants, to enable them to qualify for the 25 per cent tax? I recognize that the Hon. Member may not have an explanation and may be looking forward to an answer from the Minister of State for Finance (Mrs. McDougall).

Mr. Speaker, I thought I previously addressed that question when I said that the people in these professions invest handsomely in the economy. They take risks which, I would submit, very few Canadians are prepared to take. I congratulate them on their bravery, especially with the state of the economy at this time, and in particular the western economy, with which I am sure the Hon. Member is very familiar.

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to pursue this beyond rational limits. I appreciate the point made by the Hon. Member that we need investment in this country, and, indeed, these professional individuals would probably invest in various capacities. However, what about all the other professions which are not identified? Is the Hon. Member saying that only the professional groups identified as lawyers, dentists and doctors invest in the economy and all the other professional groups which are identified in the Income Tax Act as professional groups do not invest? I do not understand why there is a distinction between one set of professionals and another.

Mr. Speaker, following the band-aids probably will come the tourniquets; then later, as I suggested, the major surgery. I stress that that surgery is elective surgery because an election was held on the issue.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The period for questions and comments on the speech of the Hon. Member is at an end. We shall now resume debate.

November 26, 1984
Income Tax Act
Mr. Speaker-
Oh, no!

Who said that? I suspect that remark came from the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis). My hon. friend, the Hon. Member for Edmonton South (Mr. Edwards), in my opinion, Sir, was all too charitable to that Hon. Member in his opening comments. I would never say anything like that about the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap because I have listened to him for several years in this House. I listened to what he had to say today with respect to Bill C-7, and for the most part, Sir, his comments were typical New Democratic Party tax garbage. The Hon. Member did, however, zero in on one particular group of Canadians-dentists, doctors and persons in allied professions. For some reason, obviously, the New Democratic Party do not like dentists.
If anyone has gone to a dentist of late he will have easily seen the similarity between a dentist's office and the ordinary small business. The dentist has a staff, he has equipment to buy and he has an office to run. It is my personal opinion, and it is the opinion of the Government of Canada, that there is not much difference between that type of operation and what we would normally consider to be a small business. Therefore, I am particularly pleased that the provisions of the Income Tax Act as they apply to so-called non-qualifying businesses have been repealed under this Bill.
The Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap did make one valid observation, Sir, and that was that this bill is largely a Liberal Bill. To a great extent it comes to us as a result of the Budget brought in by the Hon. Marc Lalonde on February 15 of this year. That observation, which was also made by the Hon. Member for Algoma (Mr. Foster), was quite correct.
I believe what we are faced with in this Bill is a series of technical amendments to the Income Tax Act. There is no real change in the way that taxation will be levied in Canada. However, the amendments which are before us are, on balance, good ones, ones with which this House should deal as expeditiously as possible. In a sense, the February Budget of the former Minister of Finance was a way of drawing back from the disastrous MacEachen Budget of 1983. The Government of the day realized just how badly it had fared with the MacEachen Budget and in order to have a system of taxation with which Canadians could live, even if they were not particularly happy, brought in the Budget of February 15; and the Bill which was brought forward in August was the model for Bill C-7. There have been some improvements made in this Bill since August and we hope it will suit even more the present Canadian financial and taxation situation.
I am pleased that the Minister of State for Finance (Mrs. McDougall) brought this Bill in so early in the session. It shows that we on this side of the House intend to give high priority to tax matters. If one looks at the provisions of the Bill, one sees that they deal predominantly with small business taxation. The reason for this is that we believe that the small business sector of the Canadian economy is most important.
I would like to speak about some of the provisions as they affect small business. This Bill will reduce by over two-thirds the amount of legislation relating to low tax rates for small business. We, together with Hon. Members on the other side of the House, have been trying for some time to reduce the volume of the Income Tax Act and to bring in progressive simplifications.
Bill C-7 will increase access to tax savings for growing small businesses. It will reduce the cost of tax compliance, again for those small businesses. I like the provision for the elimination of the cumulative deduction account, and other speakers agree with me. Even the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap agreed with that provision so we must be doing something right on this side of the House.
The provisions dealing with the 35 per cent research and development credit and the 40 per cent investment tax credit are good. These provisions should assist investment in research and development on the part of small business. I am pleased to see that the working out computation will be dealt with on the previous year rather than on the current year in which you are claiming those tax credits, which makes it a lot easier. That is one simplification.
Some other provisions of the Bill which is before us include simplifications in the realm of taxation of charities. The Bill does not reflect the give-and-take proposals in their entirety. In fact, they reflect very little of the give-and-take proposals which have been made from time to time in this House. However, they are a step in the right direction and, as a step in the right direction, I am sure all Hon. Members of the House will support them.
There are provisions in the Bill which deal with employee stock options and the taxation consequences of giving employees stock options. I think this is, on balance, good. The intention here is to encourage stock options to be given to the employees of corporations so that they will have a vested interest in that business and will wish to see it grow and prosper. A lot of these recommendations came out of the good work of the parliamentary subcommittee which was established at the instigation of a private member of the Liberal Party in the last Parliament. Sometimes in this place we wonder whether anything eventually comes out of all the work we put into things, but this is one case where something came out of that parliamentary subcommittee. The lady who headed that parliamentary subcommittee and who originally presented the private member's motion to establish that committee is to be complimented, even though she is no longer with us.
With respect to taxation of energy and resources, the provision for recapture of depletion will assist people who invest in the oil and gas industries in Canada. There are provisions for the modification of the law which deals with expenditures after 1983 on certain wells, the treatment of them as development rather than exploration expenses, and the effect which that has on the deductions. I believe it is 30 per cent for development wells and 100 per cent for exploration wells. This is to be the changeover; it will be postponed for some two years until January 1, 1986. It will be a spur to the oil and gas industry,
November 26, 1984

especially in western Canada which was hit so badly by the national energy policy.
The Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap brought to the attention of the House the fact that these are minor modifications, and I do not think they go quite far enough. They are technical amendments that help things for the next couple of years or so, but we really have to look at the whole tax regime for exploration and development in the resource sector, oil and gas in particular, between now and 1986. We have to have something in place. It is all right to continue the present regime of PIP grants and so on until 1986 because people are locked into these programs and it would be unfair to rip up valid contracts. But we really need a new regime in Canada so that the oil and gas industry will know where it stands and will be able to make rational investment decisions based on the permanency of tax and other legislation dealing with the disposition of natural resource rights.
It will be a major task of this Government and this House of Commons over the next two years to bring in a new and steady regime to replace the existing situation which arose out of the national energy policy and a lot of other things that have upset both members of this House and the oil and gas industry for so long. I notice as well that this Bill contains a provision for a tax free roll over when, in certain circumstances, an individual transfers resource property to a taxable Canadian corporation. That will be helpful to people in that line of business.
I have a few comments, Sir, on tax assistance to people engaged in agriculture. Farmers have been having a particularly tough time over the last few years with low commodity prices and high taxes, expecially taxes on agricultural inputs such as farm fuels, et cetera. There have been a lot of discussions in the commons and in the country over capital gains taxes as they affect farmers. I am pleased with the amendments regarding the $ 120,000 amount not being subject to capital gains tax when it is rolled over into an RRSP, as well as certain provisions dealing with the transfer of family farms from one generation to another. This is a step in the right direction and something which all Members should support.
Of course, in the view of members from agricultural areas, it certainly does not go far enough. I was pleased to hear the Minister say that this matter will be referred to a parliamentary committee so that agricultural taxation, not only in respect of the Income Tax Act but customs duties and other types of taxation on agriculture, can be looked at again. Perhaps we can put a rational system in place.
By way of an aside, the three cents a litre tax rebate on farm fuels will come into effect as a result of the economic statement handed down in this House a couple of weeks ago. It certainly will be of assistance to farmers, fishermen and other people in the resource industry. As an aside to that aside, I would like to say that that tax rebate also ought to be extended to trappers. They were not specifically mentioned in the statement but they certainly are in the same line of business,
Income Tax Act
renewable resource development, and the rebate ought to be extended to the fur harvesters of Canada.
We need a radical change in the taxation of capital gains in Canada, Mr. Speaker, not only for farmers. Sometimes it is hard for someone who comes from a non-agricultural area to understand the difference between a farm, which I look upon as being small business or in certain circumstances a large business, and any other type of business. I would like to see us get out of the capital gains tax business altogether. That would be the greatest spur to investment in Canada that we could imagine. I do not think the capital gains tax brings in any great amount of revenue in comparison with the difficulty it imposes on taxpayers. Very often we are collecting taxes not on real capital gains but on inflationary gains. So this Bill is good in that it alleviates the capital gains tax in certain specified instances dealing with agricultural land, but certainly it does not go far enough and we have to look at getting rid of it altogether in Canada and going back to the pre-Benson days.
The tax provisions of Bill C-7 extend to personal income tax measures and maybe I will just go over these point by point. The ability to deduct moving expenses has been extended. This has been brought to my attention on several occasions where people have moved from Newfoundland to the Northwest Territories. In my particular area of the country long distance moves are quite common.
Then there is simplification of rules applicable to the breakdown of marriage.
Another area concerns eligible medical expenses. As you will recall, someone had to be confined to bed or to a wheelchair before they were eligible to write off the cost of certain medically required equipment. I am pleased to see that will no longer be the case. I remember question after question being asked in this House about people who common sense would say should be able to get a tax deduction for a piece of medical equipment, yet the word for word provisions of the Income Tax Act were such that they could not. This is certainly a good step.
As well, fairness in tax administration, as the Minister of National Revenue (Mr. Beatty) has said on many occasions, both as Minister and as opposition critic, is something we feel very strongly about on this side of the House. We feel taxpayers should be treated honourably and fairly, and Bill C-7 contains provisions which will enable that to be done.
I see I am running out of time, Mr. Speaker, so I will have to speed up a little bit. Perhaps out of all the provisions dealing with tax administration I will simply pick two items. The one dealing with revocation of waivers I think is important. Once a waiver had been given there was no way of revoking it and in certain circumstances the taxpayer might feel that he or she would want to do that. So this is a good move.
We on this side of the House have been talking about award of costs for many years. I am pleased to see that it is included in the legislation before us today. Some taxpayers have

November 26, 1984
Income Tax Act
incurred great expense and put a lot of time and effort into fighting tax cases. Some of those cases were brought by Revenue Canada in order to determine what the law was. I am pleased to see that there will now be a provision for the award of costs.
In summary, Mr. Speaker, these are mainly technical amendments. They have been a long time in the pipeline. Members on all sides of the House can be pleased with the input which they have had into this. It has been a combined effort by members on all sides of the House. I hope these provisions will be dealt with expeditiously in order that we can go from here to change the whole concept of taxation and address some of the matters which I have brought up in my presentation.

Mr. Speaker, I found the remarks of the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson) very interesting. I have a question with regard to his proposal to abolish the capital gains tax. I recall that during a recent election campaign a certain candidate for Prime Minister said that the rich would "pay handsomely". Could the Hon. Member explain to us how "paying handsomely" fits in with abolishing the capital gains tax? Does the Hon. Member feel it is reasonable for a millionaire who owns paintings and sells them for 100 times his original investment not to pay income tax on that gain? That is the conclusion I am arriving at from what he is saying. After all, those kinds of sales are taxed only through the capital gains mechanism. Or is the Hon. Member proposing to replace the capital gains tax with some other method of payment through which the rich will pay handsomely, to use the expression of his Leader?

Mr. Speaker, let us consider a few examples. In the days before taxation of capital gains there was a lot of incentive for prospectors to go out in the bush and look for showings. If a prospector found one mine in his lifetime he was doing much better than average. A lot of that incentive was taken away when capital gains taxes were introduced. The same is true with people who have accumulated a few dollars and want to build an apartment house. It is no longer as attractive to do that as it was in the pre-capital gains tax days.
As a result of that there are less prospectors looking for mineral showings. There are less people building apartment houses and this is showing up in the low vacancy rates in housing. I am sure that is happening in the Hon. Member's own riding. People are just not investing money in that area. Therefore, if we could reduce or eliminate the capital gains tax it would be good for Canadian society because people would make investments. People only invest if they think they are going to show a profit. They do not do it for fun. If we take away all the incentive that will not happen.
I suggested that this topic should be a prime one for discussion and examination during the course of this Parliament. There are certain difficulties with regard to transferring income into capital gains, so we must study it carefully. I make no apology for suggesting that in my opinion we would be
doing the nation a favour. We would be mobilizing capital and human energy if capital gains taxes were eliminated.

Mr. Speaker, as usual, I have listened to the eloquence of my colleague, the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson). When he was in opposition on this side of the House he was very articulate in outlining the areas which the Government should change with regard to the tax system. Now, as part of the Government, he is in a position to implement these changes. Over the next weeks and months we will look forward to seeing these changes incorporated into the tax system to make it more attractive to the investor and to make it a fairer tax system.
I would like to remind the Hon. Member that the Department of Energy, Mines and Resources recently published a book about two inches thick which identifies all of the mineral resources which are sitting dormant and theoretically could be mined. Therefore, while his concern for the prospector is valid, there is another more pressing need, and that is to find ways and means of getting those deposits developed. I propose that the only way to do that is to take action on interest rates as opposed to leaving it to the free market place, as we have, in theory, at the moment.
The Hon. Member referred to the employee stock option section of this Bill. He suggested that this was going to provide an opportunity for employees to feel much more part of an operation. Would the Hon. Member explain how someone working for Imperial Oil who owns 20 shares of that corporation is going to feel that he is a meaningful part of that corporate entity?
The Hon. Member referred to tax collection and how the Government is sensitive to the need to be compassionate in the collection of taxes. Why was it necessary to spend millions and millions of dollars and hire 350 tax collectors to collect taxes? Does the Member see this as a way to develop confidence in the people of Canada and the small business sector? Will having more tax collectors badgering people to pay taxes develop a new sense of confidence in the country?

Mr. Speaker, I wish that I had 20 shares in Imperial Oil. I do not think it really matters whether you have 20 or 2,000 shares in Imperial Oil, there is still an incentive attached. You own part of it and you can keep it or dispose of it. If you keep it and work harder, presumably you will see the value of those 20 shares increase. It is pretty obvious that unless you happen to be the chairman of the board or the president you are not going to have a great effect on the fortunes of a corporation as large as Imperial Oil. However, to deny that there is any effect whatsoever would be exactly the same as to deny that a Canadian citizen has no effect whatsoever on the Government of Canada when he or she casts that one vote out of 10 million.
A lot of corporations that give employees stock options are small corporations. Had the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap listened diligently to the presentations which were made before the parliamentary committee, he would have understood that. Very often this mechanism is used in much
November 26, 1984

smaller corporations than Imperial Oil. I think it is valid not only for the small corporations but also for the large ones.

The second question dealt with the hiring of more employees for Revenue Canada. Perhaps it was wrong to describe the extra employees as tax grabbers. There will be a lot of people required in the operation of Revenue Canada.
One of the difficulties we have now is that the people who have been employed there have been overworked. Anyone who has tried to call up the Department of National Revenue to make an inquiry with respect to an assessment or whatever knows that one cannot get through. I tried this once as an experiment. I attempted to call Zenith 4000, the office in Edmonton. I tried ten times and let the phone ring about 20 times on each occasion. It is just impossible to get through.
Many of these new employees will not be going out hounding people to pay their taxes but providing the service that taxpayers require. We will now have people who will be able to meet with a delinquent taxpayer and work out a schedule for repayment rather than just going in with a garnishee stamp. The idea behind hiring more people for the Department of National Revenue is to make the tax system more fair and equitable and to provide services that the taxpayers require.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The period for questions and comments being over, we will resume debate.

Mr. Speaker, this Bill is as important in terms of what it does not do as much as what it does provide. It makes no effort to deal with some of the real inequities and unfairness in the tax system.
The Bill addresses some of the necessary changes that are required in the tax system. These matters have been discussed on many previous occasions by Conservatives when they were in opposition and by Liberals when they were in government. It is surprising to note the changes in attitude with respect to some of these clauses. However, that seems to reflect the kind of political structure we are in. Bill C-7 does not deal at all with corporate capital giveaways, nor does it address the increasing number of loopholes within the system.
My colleague who spoke earlier suggested that there are many Canadians in this country who pay no tax at all. There is no attempt in this Bill to deal with those people, whose numbers are growing every year. In 1971 there were only eight people who made over $100,000 and paid no tax at all. By 1981 that number had increased to 1,490. The reason for this increase of almost 1,500 people who pay no tax is that there have been more and more loopholes introduced into the tax system to allow them to do so. I believe it is the Government's responsibility to review the tax sytem, to make sure that this no longer happens and that those people are taxed in some manner.
The Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson) spoke about capital gains and suggested that this was one possible method for increasing the amount of investment.
Income Tax Act
However, I would also point out to him that within the present tax system it is also a method for increasing the number of people who make more than $100,000 or $200,000 without having to pay any tax at all.
The capital gains structure as it presently exists is very unfair. The Hon. Member for Western Arctic made some very valuable comments about the need for studying capital gains and how this should be done. One of the inequities of capital gains is that one pays taxes on only half of one's capital gains, whether it is $50,000 or $500,000. You pay only on half, as if you had earned that same amount of money working. This Bill does not deal with that unfairness which has been built into the system.
It has been our view that during the past decade, while the government systematically increased spending to provide a government that cared about the people, at the same time it proceeded systematically to diminish the tax base. Consequently, that reduction in tax revenues has resulted in the kinds of deficits that we now face. The Government must now look at ways to restore that tax base which has been lost over the past 20 years. Most of that tax base has been lost as a result of tax credits to large corporations.
I am particularly interested in the attempt in this Bill to achieve some fairness for farmers. I speak particularly about that portion of the Bill which allows RRSPs to be purchased by farmers who are selling their farms and the rollover provisions for farms moving within the family.
The Conservatives came to Prince Albert in large numbers to reveal the Prince Albert manifesto. They promised real relief from the farm financial situation and have taken a couple of steps in that direction in this Bill. However, the Government has not yet made an effort to deal with the main problems facing the farming community.
Be that as it may, I am pleased that this Bill has revived the measure from the previous Bill to provide an opportunity to farmers to buy RRSPs for half of the capital gains, up to $120,000. It has been widely stated that in many cases the capital that a farmer has developed in his land is the only retirement capital he has. Consequently, he needs a mechanism that will allow him to use that capital without much of it being siphoned off for tax purposes. I congratulate the Government for introducing such a mechanism.
The Prince Albert manifesto addressed a number of other important issues which needed consideration. The Minister has indicated that these were up for study, but many of these have been studied before. I think the Conservative Party when in opposition put forward a very acceptable approach to Section 31 of the Income Tax Act and the inequities which caused farmers a lot of trouble in the last few years.
In this Bill there is a definition of a full-time farmer. I suggest that later on in Committee of the Whole deliberations it will be necessary for the Government to define exactly what it means by a full-time farmer and exactly what it means by that ability to purchase RRSPs. Over the last four or five

November 26, 1984
Income Tax Act
years the definition of a full-time farmer and a part-time farmer has become so involved, that they are so difficult to define, that no farmer who happens to work off the farm for a period of time really knows how he is going to be classified. Will this definition allow a person losing money, one who has to work off the farm, to take advantage of the RRSP situation?
We have heard from this Government about what it is going to do to help relieve the financial problems of farmers. We are looking forward to a little more action than we have in this Bill. Up until now we really have had nothing which amounted to a great deal of action to help farmers with their financial problems.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Are there any questions or comments? If not, we will resume debate.

Mr. Speaker, this is clearly an attempt on the part of our Party to make certain that the changes that go through as part of Bill C-7 do not do so in some kind of automatic and carefree way, but instead become subject to scrutiny and a general discussion about the direction in which we should be proceeding in tax policy. This is, after all, the first piece of legislation that has come before us from the federal Government dealing with the tax system. For ourselves we have felt that the priority in the tax system should be to bring in measures that establish some serious move toward fairness, some real advance toward a system that treats ordinary Canadians in at least as equitable a way as the many rich taxpayers who benefit from so many loopholes and the many corporate and personal tax advantages that allow them to escape from paying their fair share of the tax burden.
We as a Party would have brought in for priority action not the discredited past regime's efforts at some small tax changes, which were efforts many members of the Conservative Party attacked. We would have aimed to bring in changes that started to establish once and for all through at least a series of dramatic gestures a new sense in the country whereby Canadians can look forward to a tax system which is fair and just instead of a tax system which is unjust, unfair, and incredibly complicated.
We would first have moved to do something about the incredible tax breaks for the corporate sector of the economy. We would look at capital allowances provided to companies over and above the normal depreciation which can be taken off a company's corporate income. We would look at the very fast write-offs which have been provided for new investment, fast write-offs given automatically, not given to projects that otherwise would not go forward. For instance, there are the regional industrial development expansion grants which go only for specific jobs in a context where companies would not otherwise move forward. We would look at the very fast write-offs for exploration and development within the resource sector. We have seen the way in which these have increased dramatically. We have seen the conclusions of economists, quite universal on this matter here in Canada, that this attempt to funnel more
money to the corporate sector has not resulted in increased jobs. It has not even resulted in increased business investment in Canada. Instead we have seen a slowdown in investment. Despite the incredible tax breaks, we have seen the corporate sector really not establishing new jobs for Canadian workers.
We think there has to be action on the very high level of tax advantages provided the corporate sector here in Canada. That is not because we do not want to see serious efforts made to help the business community establish more employment for Canadians. We have been the people who have defended programs like the industrial and regional development program against the significant cut-back of planned expenditures which this Government has recently initiated. We believe that the way the corporate tax system has been used to provide a whole set of automatic tax credits, not related to performance, does not make economic sense. It is not fair, it is not effective, and it should not be happening.
We feel the priorities of this Government with respect to tax avoidance are simply wrong. The Government has hired a significant number of new tax inspectors to go after ordinary Canadians. At the same time officials admitted privately before the changes in secrecy rules which will make it a little more difficult to do so in the future that the largest source of tax avoidance, tranfer of payments made by corporations outside this country, do not receive the scrutiny they should.

Mr. Speaker, last week, the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) tabled the annual report on future immigration levels. I am somewhat skeptical, since I am afraid this report shows a drastic change in our immigration policy, a change for the worse. In my humble opinion, the Progressive Conservative Government is about to give up our traditional humanitarian stance for a more opportunistic one, by favouring the more
November 26, 1984

prosperous immigrants to the detriment of certain less fortunate groups.
The new economic direction the Minister of Employment and Immigration seems to be adopting is an alarming one. From the moral point of view, it is unacceptable to continue to close our doors to workers and selected workers, because after all, their ancestors built this country when it needed them to clear the land and do backbreaking labour. At the time we did not care whether immigrants had thousands of dollars to invest. Today, now that Canada is developed and is gradually recovering from the recession, must our admission criteria be financial ones, from now on?
If that is the case, it denotes an attitude that is to be condemned, because it ignores those people who are trying to join their family members in this country, while there are also thousands of people for whom Canada could be a place of refuge and provide a better life.

subtopic: CRUISE MISSILE TESTING-ADVANCE NOTIFICATION OF CIVIL AVIATION
CRUISE MISSILE TESTING-ADVANCE NOTIFICATION OF CIVIL AVIATION
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, recent reports would have it that Cruise missiles might again be tested in Canada this coming winter. There were several complaints last winter dealing with inadequate notice to civil aviators along the test route which traverses the western Northwest Territories and northern Alberta. In order to avoid unfortunate accidents, civil aviation should be advised well in advance of the time, date, and route of missile tests. Also the altitude and speed of the missile and the tracking aircraft should be published. The Department of Transport ought to issue NOTAMs with this information, not at the last minute but sufficiently in advance of the tests so that the many pilots and passengers who regularly travel along the test route will not be placed in any unnecessary danger.

subtopic: PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION OF BRIDGE BETWEEN MASSON, P.Q. AND CUMBERLAND, ONT.
PROPOSED CONSTRUCTION OF BRIDGE BETWEEN MASSON, P.Q. AND CUMBERLAND, ONT.
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, some Hon. Members on the government side seem to be both confused and divided. With the apparent support of the Hon. Member for Ottawa-Carleton (Mr. Turner), the Hon. Member for Gatineau (Mrs. Mailly) has decided that a bridge would be built between Masson (Quebec) and Cumberland (Ontario) and that a preliminary study would be started very shortly, with the approval of the Minister of State for Transport (Mr. Bouchard). On the other hand, the Hon. Member for Argenteuil-Papineau (Mrs. Bourgault) has made the following statement, as reported in the Le Droit daily:
If such a study ever takes place, it will certainly not be funded by Ottawa, for this bridge has never been listed among the government's priorities.
Are we witnessing a tempest in a teacup? Knowing the atmosphere of secrecy within which this government likes to operate, I suggest that one of its Hon. Members should at least have the decency to tell the other the time of day, unless this is a case of two Hon. Members fighting to get the upper hand. Is the government going to clear up the matter, or will he let fate decide on the taxpayers' backs whether or not we will get a bridge or a study? The Deputy Prime Minister may be the only one who knows the answer to this question, but alas, as you know, Mr. Speaker, he was struck by a strange disease on September 4 which has rendered him totally mute.
Mr. Speaker, this rightist government is acting awkwardly, and it is clear that one right hand does not know what another right hand is doing.

CANADIAN RADIO-TELEVISION AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION SUSPENSION OF CABLEVISION PROSECUTIONS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to bring to the attention of the Minister of Justice (Mr. Crosbie), the Minister of Communications (Mr. Masse), and Members of the House, a situation which has serious implications regarding confidence in the Government. Last week the Government stopped all prosecutions against cablevision operators who had ignored the regulations of the CRTC. In some of the communities involved, legitimate licensed cablevision operators who had sought and obtained CRTC recognition, and who had met all the rules and regulations contained in their licences found themselves in competition with cable operators who were operating without CRTC approval. Until recently the Department of Justice had decided to prosecute those cable companies operating in contravention of the CRTC in recognition of the legal, legitimate, and licensed cable operators, but now the Department has stopped the prosecution process.
What signal does this send to licensed cable operators? How is the licensed cable operator able to compete in such an unfair market situation? I would ask the two Ministers involved to take immediate action to stop the stay of prosecution, especially for those communities where a licensed cablevision firm is operating in competition with an unlicensed firm.

November 26, 1984

subtopic: INCIDENCE OF SUICIDE AMONG YOUNG INUIT-PLEA FOR GOVERNMENT CONSIDERATION

speechtext:
Mir. Thomas Suluk (Nunatsiaq): Mr. Speaker, the Inuit, who comprise 85 per cent of my riding, have gone through a period of tremendous cultural upheaval for the last 20 years. Although all 33 communities can now boast of modern conveniences such as education, public housing, and satellite television, the appearances are misleading. This weekend another Inuk youth terminated his own life in frustration at coping with the laws of the land.
This is not an isolated case. Many of these unfortunate events take place in communities where cultural clashes are the greatest. Many young Inuit are finding it more and more difficult to cope with modern problems affecting the North, where jobs are few and far between. The problem is compounded by the fact that our young Inuit can no longer live off the land like their predecessors.
Although many Inuit leaders are trying to address this problem, they are hampered by a lack of funds for effective programs. I am therefore calling upon the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) and the Minister of State for Youth (Mrs. Champagne) to look into the serious problems confronting Inuit youth in the riding of Nunatsiaq.

Mr. Speaker, the International Development Research Centre is one of the country's most important agencies which helps developing countries. Set up in 1970, it has built a fine reputation by helping research in poor countries into agricultural problems, health concerns, and social and economic issues. The annual budget of IDRC is in the $80-million range. Now, as a result of the Government's cuts, $10 million has had to be chopped from this year's budget. This is tragic for the poorer people of developing countries, sad for the international reputation of our country, and extremely demoralizing for IDRC staff.
It is especially tragic that these cuts hit IDRC this year as it is especially active in helping increase food production in Africa. A special focus has been on Ethiopia, where IDRC help has been going to the Institute of Agricultural Research and its Commission on Science and Technology to find more drought-resistant crop varieties and low-cost farm improvement systems.
We urge the Government to stop these cut-backs. The tragedy of African hunger cries out for more Canadian support through IDRC, not less.

Mr. Speaker, Sir John A. Macdonald was a great Canadian and a splendid parliamentarian. His legislation reflected the thinking of the great majority of his people. For example, both metric and imperial were placed in the statutes, and Canadians could use the one of their choice. As a result we have a metric money system, and imperial is used in measuring land. This made sense to the rank and file of the nation and to everyone else, that is, until the last Liberal Government came along. It said: "This freedom of choice is too simple. We will force everyone to use metric".
It was sensible where small measurements were used, such as in medicine, but completely stupid to change an excellent system of land surveys. That did not bother the Liberals; it fitted right in with their totalitarian concept of telling the people what was good for them. Scores of farmers exclaimed: "We are foreigners in our own land. We don't know how much we are getting for a bushel of wheat any more". Shoppers were dumb founded, not knowing how many pounds of meat they were getting for their dollar.
The simple fact is that there is a place for metric and a place for imperial. The people should make the choice, not the Government. Canadian people are not illiterate-they will not be changing acres to hectares, or bushels to hectolitres.
This Government will restore sanity to our weights and measures by following the example of that great Conservative Prime Minister of the past and doing what the people want. Down with compulsion, and up with the people!
Hear, hear!

subtopic: PROTECTION OF THE UNBORN-PLEA FOR LEGISLATIVE ACTION
PROTECTION OF THE UNBORN-PLEA FOR LEGISLATIVE ACTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the acquittal of Dr. Henry Morgentaler has made a mockery of our jury system and is clear evidence that our abortion laws require immediate review to ensure more protection is given to the unborn. The acquittal is a serious indictment of the integrity of our criminal justice system. How can anyone have confidence in any justice system when a self-confessed criminal gloats over being acquitted after having committed a crime?
Abortion is wrong, Mr. Speaker. Human life is precious. From the moment of conception, life begins, and absolutely no person has the right to take that life under any circumstances. It is uncivilized and indecent for a nation to condone murder in whatever form, and in my view, abortion is murder.
While visiting our country, Pope John Paul II had this to say about abortion:
This unspeakable crime against human life which rejects and kills life at its beginning sets the stage for despising, negating and eliminating the life of adults and for attacking the life of society.
I call on the Government, Mr. Speaker, to amend the Criminal Code to afford greater protection for the innocent unborn of our society, and to petition the Province of Ontario to appeal the Morgentaler acquittal immediately. To do otherwise would be to breed disrespect for the rule of law and the sanctity of life.

subtopic: DECISION BASED ON MEDICAL CONSULTATION-PLEA FOR REPEAL OF LAW
DECISION BASED ON MEDICAL CONSULTATION-PLEA FOR REPEAL OF LAW
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I too rise to make a few comments with respect to the acquittal of Dr. Henry Morgentaler by a jury in Toronto. I believe it is time that Parliament recognized that Canadians demand a change in this unjust law. Four times Henry Morgentaler has been tried before a jury and four times he has been acquitted. When will Parliament recognize that the fundamental decision on the question of abortion should be left to a woman in consultation with her doctor?
I disagree fundamentally with the views of the Liberal critic of the Solicitor General's Department with respect to this matter, and I urge Parliament to recognize that the present law is unworkable. The law has resulted in delays being faced by women from rural areas and women in areas which do not have therapeutic abortion committees. Those delays can in some cases endanger the life of the mother.
The present law is unworkable. Rather than returning to the days of the dark ages as advocated by the Liberal Member, I suggest that we move forward by repealing the provisions of the Criminal Code and listening to the voices of Canadians who are crying out for justice in this area of the law. I believe
Oral Questions
that Henry Morgentaler has blazed a path for Canadian women. He has been tried and has served time in jail. I think it is about time that Canadian Members of Parliament recognized that this law should be repealed.

DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY, MINES AND RESOURCES PROPOSED RELOCATION OF OFFICE FROM SUMMERS1DE. P.E.I., TO CHARLOTTETOWN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last week the people of my riding were given the unwelcome news that Prince Edward Island's conservation and renewable energy office is being moved from Summerside, which is in my riding, to Charlottetown, which is in the riding of the Minister of State for Tourism (Mr. McMillan). To the people of my area this means a loss of 12 federal jobs, in an area in which federal jobs are a real rarity.
Prince Edward Island is in the unfortunate position of having to rely on oil as an energy source, and this results in islanders having to pay the highest energy costs in Canada. The CHIP and COSP programs which are being abandoned by the Government are very important to the people of my riding and to the people of Prince Edward Island as a whole. There are still many islanders who have not yet been able to afford to participate in the programs and it now looks as though they will not have the chance to do so.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Right Hon. Prime Minister.
In the light of the new directives issued by the Prime Minister last Friday, concerning communications between the Public Service of Canada and reporters and the Canadian public, could the Right Hon. Prime Minister inform the House whether, before making this decision, the Government, as it has since the beginning of this session, used the word "consultation" as its theme, and could the Right Hon. Prime Minister

November 26, 1984
Oral Questions
inform the House whether his Government consulted the press gallery, the institutions that communicate with the public and the Public Service unions, before issuing directives that effectively prevent any communication between public servants and the Canadian public?

subsubtopic: INQUIRY WHETHER "CONSULTATION" IS THEME OF NEW GUIDELINES
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, of course the end of my hon. friend's question is entirely erroneous. The purpose and in fact the wording of these directives is such that we are trying to expand communications, not restrict them. I think the person in charge of communications in my office had a meeting with the president of the press gallery. 1 do not know whether other consultations are taking place, but I know there have been several.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask a supplementary question of the Right Hon. Prime Minister. In his book entitled Where I Stand, the Right Hon. Member indicated that all of the briefing papers related to the development of any policy should be made public. How can it be that he can write such a thing before the election campaign, but today he will not permit any bureaucrats to deal off the record with background information? How can the Prime Minister not allow bureaucrats to give the press background information about the different political options faced by the Government at the time of making certain decisions? How can the public understand these policies if bureaucrats cannot say anything without being quoted in the press?

Mr. Speaker, I am delighted that my hon. friend has read my book. However, it is clear that he did not read the guidelines. While I acknowledge that the guidelines are not perfect, they are designed to be helpful and to be open. The public servants are not there either to defend or criticize government policy. Pursuant to their oath, public servants are there to explain policy objectively at all times. The guidelines provide for that in abundance. Moreover, in the spirit of openness, they suggest to public servants that they ought to feel completely free in regard to their comments, and to be on the record and be quoted. That is consistent with a policy of openness. Those guidelines were prepared not with a view to shutting down communications but to opening them up and placing them in a reasonable perspective, and that is all they were about.

Mr. Speaker, if a bureaucrat were to decide to give some background information to the press that would show to the press and to the Canadian public that there were flaws in policies but that there were ways to remedy the situation by giving the public different options, can the Prime Minister give the House the guarantee that this bureaucrat would not be penalized by curtailing his advancement in public life?

Mr. Speaker, if a public servant found a serious flaw in public policy, then, pursuant to the oath taken by that public servant, he should inform the Minister of it and not anyone else. That is his responsibility and that is what parliamentary democracy and a sense of responsibility are all about. We are trying to ensure that that public servant, if contacted by anyone, quite freely and objectively explains government policy in the manner that he feels is appropriate, without any recrimination or reprisal by us. It is an invitation to public servants to feel free to go on the record, in those areas where they are responsible, to explain public policy and to do so with the full knowledge that they have the backing of the Government and the House of Commons.

Mr. Speaker, the public servants are completely free to explain government policy. That is what was stipulated and has been the case. All we are asking, to ensure objectivity and protection for the Public Service, is that this be done pursuant to these guidelines. It is not in any way intended to do anything other than, first, to ensure the right of the public to know and, second, to ensure the independence and impartiality of the Public Service.

Mr. Speaker, I repeat, it is encouraging so far, but let us be more precise. In the case of the CBC an $85 million budget cut has been announced, and in the case of Employment and Immigration $400 million has been cut. And, if so, is the Prime Minister now telling the House that if an inquiry is made, either by the media or by a Member of Parliament, we will be able to get that impact information from a civil servant?

No, not at
all, Mr. Speaker. What we are saying is that government policy, and this has always been the case in this country, once fairly arrived at by the duly elected Government of Canada, is explained by public servants, is defended by the Government, and is criticized by the Opposition. The Public Service is there to explain the policy of the duly elected Government.
I am sure my hon. friend quite understands the impropriety inherent in his suggestion because it would effectively paralyze the Public Service in its right and obligation to provide Ministers with unfettered and unvarnished advice. I am sure the Hon. Member, given his respect for the parliamentary system, would not want to paralyze the operations of Parliament in that way. We want to protect the public servants. We want to make sure they are not criticized for being political, and we do not want to politicize the Public Service. That is why the protection is described in the manner in which it is.
Hear, hear!

I say to the Prime Minister that he cannot have it both ways. He cannot, eight minutes ago, say that civil servants can give information about impact in the future, and eight minutes later say: "Well, if you are going to be specific, they cannot". Either the Prime Minister is for open government, freedom of expression within the parliamentary system, or he is not.
The Prime Minister must make himself clear. In the past we have been provided with forecasts of the impact of programs. Is the new Conservative Government not even going to give us that information?
It is the same old bunch.

Mr. Speaker, we are continuing to debate the principles associated with Bill C-7. In our opinion, it is a question that concerns the degree of priority the Government has given to what is essentially a housekeeping Bill as opposed to some more fundamental initiatives that would do something about the unfairness of the tax system.
We are particularly concerned about the way in which the Government, in an effort to draw more tax revenue, has focused on individual taxpayers through the establishment of a new set of inspectors to deal with them as opposed to focusing on the corporate sector.
Before we rose at one o'clock I was dealing with the question of transfer of payments by large corporations, both Canadian and foreign, and the way that permits tax avoidance to take place. That costs us money.
In the past we have heard comments from officials in the Ministry of National Revenue that indicate very clearly that they do not have enough inspectors to be able effectively to police the large number of transactions that take place across borders by Canadian and foreign corporations dealing with their own subsidiaries. There are classic cases, such as Canadian companies with subsidiaries in the Bahamas, or Bermuda, which on paper will sell items to that subsidiary and then buy them through other subsidiaries, with the material never actually moving back and forth from one country to another. In each case, the effort is to avoid tax responsibilities and tax levies here in Canada.
Instead of concentrating on these important examples of tax avoidance where literally millions of dollars are lost to the Canadian authorities, the tax department in this country has focused on small Canadians. My colleague, the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis), has talked about a number of these cases in the context of British Columbia. With respect to my constituency of Essex-Windsor, we have discovered that many low-paid waitresses have been the focus of detailed investigations by the tax authorities of this country. We have seen dozens of women who often work part-time for very low wages being harassed by the tax authorities because of suspicion on their part that these women have not been declaring the tips which they received as waitresses.
In fact, as a result of detailed investigations by the Hon. Member for Windsor-Walkerville (Mr. McCurdy) and myself, we have discovered that people affected in this case are being attacked by Revenue Canada even though in many cases these
Income Tax Act
women have kept careful records of the tips they have received. Their strong feelings have been conveyed to those tax authorities that this was deliberate harassment rather than any kind of fair attempt to get a sense of what was really going on in their personal finances.
We suggest that the Government, rather than giving priority to tidying up tax matters left by the last regime and making a systematic attempt to harass yet more individual Canadians through new tax inspectors, should be making an effort to tackle the tax avoidance problem associated with transfer pricing and attempting to establish more fairness in the tax system by improving the corporate and personal tax system.
It is fairness in the personal tax system which is perhaps the largest problem about which we have heard from our constituents throughout the country. Our Party believes that the tax system should be a good deal more progressive. While the tax system looks progressive on paper at the moment, when one actually examines the effective marginal rate of taxation as analysed this past year by the National Anti-Poverty Organization in a detailed report, one finds that the effective marginal tax rate for those making over $50,000 a year is only 29 per cent. The rate for those earning between $40,000 and $50,000 a year is only 29 per cent. Even for those earning $35,000 per year the effective rate is only 28 per cent once you take into account income which is exempted from tax through various exemptions. That is not a very steep increase in the tax system reflecting the principle to which I think most Canadians hold. If you earn more you should pay a higher share of the dollars you are receiving to the personal income tax system.
We are also concerned within the income tax system about the way we continue as a country to rely on deductions rather than tax credits. As we know, a tax deduction for a registered retirement savings plan of $5,000 is worth very much less to somebody who is making, let us say, $25,000 a year than it is to somebody who is making $50,000 a year. Even though the progressive nature of the tax system is not great, nevertheless the marginal rate of tax is higher on that $5,000 for the person who is earning $50,000 a year.
We urge the Government to move to reform our system by shifting from a system based on deductions to a system based on tax credits, following the principle of the child tax credit scheme which is one of the few examples in the tax system of a tax credit rather than a deduction approach. We also suggest that the system of tax expenditure needs to be brought back into our budget. A number of my colleagues have already made this point. We consider it serious and important that we have as taxpayers a continuing record in which various tax exemptions and tax advantages are being shared across the income classes and throughout the country.
Finally with respect to the income tax system, I urge the Government as it conducts a more comprehensive analysis of changes that need to be made to take a careful look at the tax credit for children. At present this tax credit has given us a lump sum. The result is that many poor women go to tax

November 26, 1984
Income Tax Act
agencies of various kinds and receive their tax credit prior to receiving it from the income tax department. They have to pay from 10 per cent to 15 per cent of the tax credit to the tax agency.
I suggest we establish a system which sees to it that that tax credit is paid in monthly sums to families affected so that people receive the money not in a lump sum but automatically, in the same way as family allowances or old age pensions are received. It seems to me this would make it easier for families who need the child tax credit; they would then receive it in a more effective way and it would make more of a contribution toward alleviating poverty.
We as a Party have been arguing on tax issues for many years. We have had reference to the Carter Commission by a number of speakers. We feel, and it is one of the reasons we are prolonging this debate today, that it is very important to have a full-scale, comprehensive and effective review of our tax system. Our leader, the Hon. Member for Oshawa (Mr. Broadbent), suggested in the election campaign that we should set up a royal commission on taxation. This could take in the whole set of issues we have been talking about today. A royal commission could bring some of the best minds in our country to look at our tax system and see if we could not make it a much fairer instrument for economic growth and equity. Many people in this House have been speaking about this since the start of our parliamentary session.
We have today what is, in effect, a housekeeping measure from the past regime. We hope in the future that we will see serious efforts at tax reform in the areas I have been talking about. We hope the Government will be prepared to take up our suggestion of a royal commission on taxation to try to establish a sense of fairness, a sense of efficiency and a sense of contributing to economic growth which all Canadians hope to see in the tax system.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Are there any questions or comments? If not, we will resume debate.

Mr. Speaker, it was not my intention originally to debate this Bill but I think I must make some comments on suggestions made earlier today by the Hon. Member for Western Arctic (Mr. Nickerson). He proposed that there be no tax on capital gains. I thought that was a rather interesting proposition when one considers it in the context of the over-all philosophy of income tax in general. It seems to be inherent in the whole structure that if one owns land and makes money on it, if one makes an investment and makes money on it, or if one has dividend earnings, this is in some way superior in the kind of treatment it deserves compared to income earned by dint of hard work.
I do not think I have ever heard it suggested that there be a depreciation allowance for the physical damage that results from a lifetime of hard work. It seems to me, from the point of view of the Canadian worker, that there should be some focusing on this aspect of our taxation system. Why do we have a taxation system that is so determinately punitive to the poor and to those who must make their earnings by physical
labour? What is the philosophical premise on the basis of which those who invest in fine art or property may keep much more of what they earn compared to those who work in the mines, in the factories, in the restaurants and so on?
My colleague the Hon. Member for Essex-Windsor (Mr. Langdon) has referred to the situation in Windsor where waitresses have been harassed because it is assumed that some trivial amounts of money are not being reported for income tax purposes, irrespective of the fact that upon request to do so they have supplied all the information on the basis of which they can be properly taxed.
I note this strange dichotomy also permits Revenue Canada to harass those who plead their cases to those who would want to be their elected representatives. There is clear evidence that those who have reported their circumstances, recorded this pattern of harassment, have been harassed yet more. I hope in the future, the not too distant future, that this Government will begin to right the disproportionate imposition on the poor of the taxation burden.
There have been repeated references to the Conservative progressivity of the tax system and to the need for a minimum income tax. There have been references to the lightening of the burden of large corporations and to the special treatment accorded to doctors, lawyers, dentists and so on. I do not think we need a further recital of those facts to make it clear beyond any reasonable doubt that there is a need for considerable reform, reform which will be fair not only with respect to particular types of tax incentives, deductions and so on, but in addressing the fundamental issue to which I referred earlier, that is the fundamental difference in treatment or the way in which we regard those who make their money by physical labour compared with those who make money simply because they have money.
