speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Minister of State (Finance)) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-9, an Act to amend the Customs Act and the Customs Tariff, be read the second time and referred to the Committee of the Whole.
She said: Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to put Bill C-9 before the House today. It would enact the amendments to the Customs Act and the Customs Tariff set out in the notice of Ways ands Means motion tabled on November 8. Our Government is proceeding with this legislation early because of its vital importance to Canada's trade performance.
All Hon. Members of the House know that there is a general movement toward freer trade world-wide. This Bill enhances Canada's commitment to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. These measures were originally brought before the House by the previous government on February 15, 1984. Bill C-9 is particularly important because it will enhance Canada's participation in the multilateral trading system by implementing a new method of valuing goods for customs purposes in line with our GATT obligations.
The Bill also introduces certain amendments to the Customs Tariff related to the implementation of this new valuation system. It expands the duty-free product coverage of the Customs Tariff in line with the expanded coverage under the GATT aircraft agreement. It removes the condition for certain tariff items that goods must be of a class or kind made or not made in Canada in order to qualify for specified rates, as well as providing for a number of miscellaneous tariff changes.
With respect to amendments to the Customs Act found in Part I of the Bill, it might be helpful if I described the context within which Canada decided to change its valuation system as of January 1, 1985. For many years there has been a growing recognition among the world's major trading nations that the openness of the international trading system could be strengthened by moving to more standard and transparent procedures which affect the flow of trade.
Since Canada relies to a great extent on international trade for our economic well-being, it is crucial that we support and participate in these multilateral efforts to harmonize international trade procedures.
One of the major initiatives of the Tokyo Round of multilateral trade negotiations concluded in 1979 was the establishment of a customs valuation code, under which all major trading nations of the world would establish the value of imported goods for the purpose of assessing customs duty in the same manner. By knowing the rules of the game in advance, exporters and importers alike would have greater certainty in conducting their business transactions in international as well as in domestic markets. Under the customs valuation code and in the proposed legislation now before the House, the price paid by the importer to the exporter for the imported goods will be the value on which duty is applied unless certain clearly defined conditions exist.
Customs Act
Those of us who are familiar with the current Canadian system realize that this approach is quite different from the one currently applied wherein the value for duty is, as a general rule, the price at which like goods are sold in the exporter's domestic market.
In spite of the advantages foreseen in adopting this code and the fact that Canada was able to obtain greater access to more markets as a result, this decision was not made without costs.
Many of our trading partners had customs valuation systems which closely approximated the provisions of the code. Their adherence to the code required only minor adjustments on the part of their business communities and customs officials. Canada's system of customs evaluation, on the other hand, was unique and our implementation of the code required a substantially greater reorientation of customs procedures.
In addition, analyses indicated that the base upon which some goods would be valued for duty would be lowered and the level of protection afforded to Canadian manufacturers by the tariff would be diminished. Thus, during the Tokyo Round Canada attached two conditions to the adoption of the customs valuation code. The first was a four-year extension to the deadline for implementing the new valuation system. While our GATT trading partners agreed to bring their systems into line with the code by January 1, 1981, Canada's obligation to implement the code will be January 1, 1985.
The second was our right to increase tariff rates, wherever necessary, to maintain the same level of production. Against this background it was extremely important for the Canadian business community to have the fullest opportunity to comment upon the legislation implementing the code and upon the effect its implementation would have on their tariff protection. Through the Tariff Board individuals were encouraged to make their views known and public hearings were held. The vast majority of recomendations made by the Tariff Board following these hearings were accepted for implementation. In summary, these amendments to the Customs Act will provide over the longer term more certainty and clarity for importers.
Since these provisions are also reflected in the statutes of our trading partners, we can be sure that a similar certainty is available to our exporters. Indeed, this type of transparency and openness can help to strengthen the multilateral trading system and increase world trade to the benefit of all.
Three aspects of the proposed Customs Tariff amendments contained in Part II of the Bill are related to the new valuation system. They are intended to maintain protection which could have been lost by Canadian producers resulting from the implementation of the new valuation system. I must emphasize that we are not proposing-and it is important to mention that we cannot propose-under our international obligations increased or new protection for these individual items.
First, tariff rate increases are contained in Schedule I of the Bill of individual items where the termination of the current system would lower the value of the goods on which duty is collected. These rate increases have been recommended by the Tariff Board following a series of public hearings. However,

November 26, 1984
Customs Act
certain adjustments were made to the Board's proposals to reflect the scheduled Tokyo Round multilateral trade negotiations reductions and to reflect certain concerns of the business community and our trading partners.
Second, the customs valuation code does not allow the use of the current ministerial prescriptions whereby the Minister of National Revenue (Mr. Beatty) can establish values for duty for certain classes of goods in cases where values cannot otherwise be determined under the law. To replace some of these ministerial prescriptions, the Bill would implement an advance of 25 per cent of the existing tariff rate for used and less than prime quality goods. This was also a proposal of the Tariff Board developed after discussion with interested sectors of the Canadian business community.
In order to ensure that this advance is applied only where necessary, the legislation would allow the Governor in Council to make regulations to define these goods, to exclude certain goods from the application of the advance and to allow for suspension of the application where appropriate. Finally, as a new measure, importers will be able to avail themselves of the appeal procedures contained in the Customs Act when used and less than prime quality goods and the tariff rate advance are in question.
I might add that consultations with our trading partners have also been completed. They accept these measures as being compatible with our international rights and obligations.
Effective January 1, 1985, Part II of this Bill will also implement the expanded duty-free product coverage of the GATT Agreement on trade in civil aircraft. Since Canada already extended duty-free entry to most of the 32 new-product categories now covered by the agreement, only minor inclusions need to be made to our duty-free provision. However, export opportunities to markets of the signatory nations including the United States, European communities and Japan will be improved as a result of their removing tariffs on these 32 categories of products.
As a result of Tariff Board recommendations, this Bill also removes a condition established for 19 tariff items that imported items must be of a class or kind made or not made in Canada in order to be allowed entry at specified tariff rates. The changes being proposed represent only some items contained in the board's proposals. The remaining items are being held for consideration at a later date.
Effective February 16, 1984, the Bill also introduces a number of miscellaneous tariff changes. One change is an increase in the limit for duty and tax-free entry of unsolicited gifts from $25 to $40. This will be welcomed by Canadians who receive gifts from friends and relatives abroad and is also consistent with the limits established by other countries.
Duty-free entry is also being extended for a wide range of capital equipment used by semi-conductor manufacturers. These companies now export over 90 per cent of their production, and this measure will assist them in lowering their costs and help them in export markets. A number of other minor
changes are included in the Bill which respond to requests from the private sector or which resolve certain technical administrative problems for customs officials.
In conclusion, let me emphasize that the measures proposed in this Bill are very significant because they will enhance Canada's contribution to the multilateral trading system by bringing Canada's customs valuation procedures into line with those of our trading partners. They are also significant because they are of benefit to many sectors of the Canadian business community. I hope that the House will agree that they are worthy of speedy passage, bearing in mind Canada's international commitment to implement the GATT valuation code by January 1, 1985.

Mr. Speaker, we had a most interesting morning as we heard Members of the government side discover new virtues in the measures introduced this morning, measures which in most cases were identical to those introduced in the last Parliament through the Lalonde budget. It is interesting how measures which would ruin the country in February have now become, under a new Conservative Government, measures well worthy of support.
We find ourselves in the same situation with the current legislation. This legislation seems to be virtually identical to measures introduced in the February 15 Budget. The present measures to amend the Customs Act and Customs Tariff have been combined, but I cannot see any essential difference between the two. There are some small differences in drafting, one or two differences in timing, and the lack of seven further tariff rate increases which were proposed in 1984. Otherwise, the measures seem to be identical to those of February, 1984.
I shall now wait with great interest to hear Members on the government side tell us what good measures these are, whereas last February they were telling us how disastrous they were.

Bill C-9 provides that goods being imported into Canada will be valued according to their transaction value or the value of the goods as paid by the importer. At present, the value of a good being imported is assessed at the fair market value of the good in the country of export. Perhaps I can use an example. If a Canadian importer were to import Sony television sets from Japan, under the present system, the Sony television sets would arrive in Canada and would be assessed a customs duty based upon what Canadian officials would determine to be their fair market value in Japan. Under this new provision, we have a system in place under which the Sony television sets would arrive in Canada and would be assessed by customs officials a duty based upon the value the Canadian importer paid for those television sets. That simply brings us into line with the system used by most of our trading partners and certainly by all of our major trading partners.
I believe it is important to recognize that the present system under which we have been operating and which is in place at the moment carries with it the potential for erecting a form of non-tariff barrier. If the Government wanted to slow down the flow of a particular good into Canada, it might lower its estimation of the fair market value of the good being imported. Then the good would be coming into Canada at a price lower than it sold for in the country of export. That would then allow Canada to lay a charge of dumping and the Government could proceed with anti-dumping actions. Essentially, Mr. Speaker, that erection of a not-so-subtle tariff wall could happen if that were the kind of action we wanted to take.
The new system that we are debating presently and that is currently being followed by our major trading partners would remove the potential of setting up a non-tariff barrier. The valuation of imported goods being in accordance with their transaction value will eliminate this arbitrary nature and establish a fair and therefore more neutral system. I think anyone who has either worked in the area of import-export or is familiar with the customs process would recognize the advantage of this particular change. For that reason, we shall certainly see that the Bill receives rapid passage.
I would like, however, to use this opportunity to mention two or three other things. When dealing with the nitty-gritty of Bill C-9 and looking at the various changes to the tariffs, we see that it poses all sorts of questions. I do not think that second reading is the time to raise those questions. For example, to make the case, toilet bowls imported into Canada that are made of a certain china mix would be charged a general perferential tariff of 9 per cent. However, urinals that are being imported into the country would come in free under the same tariff. These are some of the interesting questions which could be addressed during the clause-by-clause discussion, to identify why toilet bowls are treated differently from urinals.
I would like to take a moment during second reading debate on this extremely important Bill to reflect on the discussion which has occurred across the country in recent weeks, with some enthusiasm, concerning the whole matter of free trade. It
Customs Act
involves either sectoral free trade, as has been witnessed over the past number of months with respect to the farm implements, computer information and the like, or general free trade. I have not been enthused or encouraged by the love-in which has occurred between the new Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) and the President of the United States in terms of their coming together as friends and the indication of what it might mean for Canada in terms of developing a sound national economy. Neither have I been encouraged by the comments made in recent weeks by the Government with respect to FIRA. I have never sorted out in my own mind what the fear of FIRA was all about, recognizing that almost every country of which I am familiar has some form of FIRA process in place. Many of those processes are much more involved and complicated than our present and past FIRA regulations. I have never been convinced that legitimate investors and legitimate businesses have been hindered in entering into the Canadian economy as a result of FIRA. If they are not prepared to lay out clearly how their activities will be of benefit to our country, I am not certain that we should be so enthusiastic about welcoming them to Canada.
Canada today has some real problems associated with the branch plant economy. The fact that Canada has had tariff walls to a certain extent has resulted in certain firms being forced to open branch plants in Canada in order to have access to the domestic Canadian market. That has created both advantages and disadvantages. The advantage is that there is a plant in place, jobs are being created and there is a value added to the general economy. If the tariff walls were removed and there were to be free trade between Canada and the United States-and if there were a North American common market, which President Reagan speaks of and for which many Ministers opposite have indicated enthusiasm-then the branch plants would have no reason to be in Canada. We would find many of them simply moving back to their head offices. Consequently, a free trade situation might result in a significant reduction in economic activity and job creation in Canada.
On the other hand, we must recognize the downside of the branch plant economy. It has resulted in a situation where, for many, there has been little if any incentive to expand their operations and to seek new market opportunities elsewhere. If their total rationale for existing in Canada is simply to serve the Canadian market, why would they expand overseas? Why would they open up research and development facilities if all they really are is a branch plant of an American or other foreign parent company?
It is a Catch-22 situation. But we should not simply fall all over ourselves in enthusiasm over free trade, particularly when in the United States virtually every single action before Congress today that touches on the American economy is one of protectionism. The Americans are implementing stronger procurement policies. "Buy American" has never before been so strong. All sorts of subtle tariff walls are being thrown up in terms of imports. When that process is going on in the United States Congress, and there are approximately 27 Bills which

November 26, 1984
Customs Act
Congress is to examine that will essentially place a protective wall around a certain sector of the American economy, for us to be leaping for glee at the concept of free trade somehow makes me very nervous. For that reason, we should move very cautiously.
Recognizing how important trade is and how important it is to develop a strong manufacturing sector within the Canadian economy, we should look for a moment at one of our major trading partners other than the United States, and that is Japan. In 1983, we exported coal, lumber, rape-seed, wood pulp, wheat, meat and other commodities to Japan. We imported automobiles, telecommunications equipment, photographic goods, televisions, radios, phonographs and similar types of good from Japan. I think that serves as an example of one of the fundamental problems which we face as an exporting country. The goods which Canada exports encourage the development of our traditional resource sector at the expense of the development of a strong manufacturing sector. That manufacturing sector is labour-intensive. It will create jobs, and a stable long-term economy will be developed.
In short, as we move into discussions of free trade, particularly with the United States, it must be done in a much more open fashion. Those discussions must allow all major players to have an opportunity to express their views, whether they be small manufacturers, large national corporations, labour groups or others involved at various levels of government. We must provide an opportunity for them to ensure that whatever decision is made, either on a general basis or on a sectoral basis, is made in the best interests of Canada.
I would like to return briefly to Bill C-9 which I am pleased the Minister has introduced. It is a step in the right direction in that it allows us to examine the whole business of what goods should be kept out of the country as a result of tariffs and what goods should be attracted to the country. Particularly, I want to bring to her attention the differentiation in tariff rates. Of course, the Minister is well aware that there are different rates. The Bill cites the British preferential tariff, the most favoured nation tariff, the general tariff and the general preferential tariff. As Canada takes on its rightful role as a major trading nation, that being to assist developing countries which have commodities that Canada wishes to use, I think it is important for us to recognize that in some areas our existing trade categories may not reflect the concern which we have for many developing countries. Perhaps the time is not far off when we will have to look at the manner in which we categorize our trading preferences. By looking at that area we might be able to take steps which would enhance our trading relations with certain developing countries.
We look forward as a Party, Mr. Speaker, to examining the clause-by-clause element of Bill C-9. I would like to indicate to the Minister that she can be assured of our speedy support to have it in place.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to just say a few words in connection with the Bill. There are
really two cases to which I want to refer. The first case happened in Calgary where a dentist ordered supplies from the United States. The dentist lives about 35 miles or 40 miles outside of Calgary and the day these goods came in he was very busy and unable to go into Calgary to pick them up. He wanted to send someone else, so he phoned the customs office and asked what the cost was so he could send along the money. They would not tell him the cost and told him he would have to come in himself. I feel it is pretty ridiculous that the dentist could not send a messenger to pick up a parcel which was sent from the United States in his name. There was nothing illegal about those goods. The customs people refused to tell him the amount so he could send a cheque.
I would like to urge the Hon. Minister to look at the way in which some of these customs officials have been acting in the performance of their duties. There is no call for this type of procedure at all.
The other point I want to mention briefly is that for a long time there seemed to be a practice of not putting any duty on equipment which was going to be used to produce food, in other words, farm equipment. Within the last few years this practice has been gradually changing. Last year a move was made to put custom duties on this equipment, and the farmer had to wait for as long as six months in order to get his money back. When one is buying heavy equipment which costs $18,000, $25,000 or $50,000, one does not have the resources to wait for six months for a refund.
I would like to urge the Minister to consider that equipment that is coming into this country for the production of food should come in duty free. There should not be a customs tax on this type of equipment because otherwise it simply means that we increase the cost of food to the consumer and put the farmer in that much more of a difficult position. If this tax is going to be refunded later, why go through all the rigmarole of collecting the money from the farmer, have him apply to get it back, and then make him wait six months for a refund? It is just a rigmarole which should not be tolerated. I would urge that there be no customs duty on agricultural equipment, because we want to keep the cost of food as low as possible. The layer after layer of costs we pile onto the shoulders of the farmer will eventually have to be paid by the consumer. I believe there is a sound argument for saying that any equipment which comes into Canada for the production of food should come in duty free.

Mr. Speaker, I suppose that what I want to do in my remarks, really is to agree with the Hon. Member who just spoke, to some extent. The concern of our Canadian West about tariffs is not a new phenomenon at all. For a long time the western farmer has been faced with having to buy everything on the protected market and sell everything on the free market. Consequently, there is a section of Canada, and, unfortunately, it is the western part of Canada, which is much more affected by tariffs and customs than are other parts of Canada. Therefore, the West has generally objected to the level and the structures of both tariff and non-tariff barriers for two basic reasons;
November 26, 1984

first, as pointed out by the previous speaker, tariff barriers or non-tariff barriers do increase the price of goods to the consumer. Therefore, the consumer pays a great deal more, particularly for production costs, than he would otherwise have to pay. Second, quite often the West has trouble selling goods on the foreign market because of import barriers. Our trading partners are much slower to deal with us when they know that we have high tariffs for goods which they want to sell.
It is very difficult, Mr. Speaker, to measure the actual costs or the benefits of Canada's protectionist policies. So much depends on the consumption patterns and on the degree to which domestic producers use the products. However, if one recognizes that the consumers' price is higher as a result of tariffs and that this tariff cost is distributed across the country according to the distribution of the consumers, then by dividing the costs by the number of consumers, one can actually come up with a cost per individual. Using this method one finds that each man, woman and child in Canada paid an extra $132.62 in 1983 as a result of import tariffs.
It becomes, therefore, important that we take a look at what industries in the country and what parts of the country are affected by these import tariffs. In western Canada the tariff cost to consumers was close to $1 billion in 1983. Yet it ended up affecting only 271,000 jobs in the manufacturing market. If one compares this to the eastern part of the country, to Quebec and Ontario, there is a much more positive effect. In fact, if we look at the tariffs in Canada and compare the East with the West, we find that the effect of tariffs on the West is negative. It costs us money all the time. We do not get enough effect from the barriers to be of any value to us in the West. In the East, in Ontario and Quebec, the tariffs are positive. In other words, removing them would be harmful, but removing them in the West would do us good. That is something that we must recognize and balance out in some way so that no part of the country is hurt. The Hon. Member who spoke previously indicated that one way of doing this would be to pick certain specific products or certain areas of the country and make sure that they would be less affected than they are under present circumstances.
I think it is important, Mr. Speaker, when looking at a Bill like this, that we consider the total tariff structure and its effect on the entire country rather than on specific areas or specific industries.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Are there questions and comments on the Hon. Member's speech? If not, we shall resume debate.

Mr. Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to have the opportunity to participate in this debate, and I will do so very briefly. I wanted to raise a few concerns I have about the shoe industry which is very important in my constituency. It employs several hundred people, principally around the Alexandria area which has one plant manufacturing all of the Adidas tennis shoes in this country as well as several other makes.
Customs Act
The previous government had extended the quotas on shoes until March 31, 1986, I believe. Beyond that, we still do not know what the plans are for that particular industry. We know that the industry is extremely concerned and has serious worries as to the future. It would like to know if the Government has yet formulated any plans and, if so, would it be willing to share them with this House at this time? I think we should remember that it is very difficult for our country to compete with some of the other shoe manufacturing countries, especially when you consider that almost 50 per cent of the shoes manufactured in the world are done so in the underdeveloped or so-called developing countries. Their labour is much cheaper than ours. We must recognize the fact that many people who work in our shoe industry here in Canada are indeed very low paid workers. Shoe imports in Canada in 1966 were only of the order of 10 per cent. By 1970, it had increased to 20 per cent. By 1977, it was 36 per cent, and I understand that it is now somewhere around 60 per cent. All this, notwithstanding the fact that the anti-dumping tribunal made several investigations in the area and succeeded in eliminating some of the damaging dumping of shoes onto our markets. Notwithstanding all of the restrictions we have had in the past, our industry is still suffering, and it is an industry which is very important to our country. Certainly it is very important in Ontario and Quebec as it is indeed in the riding of Glengarry-Prescott-Russell.
We should also be aware of the fact that most employees of shoe factories in this country are women and they are, as I stated previously, in low paying jobs. Therefore, we cannot say that shoes are expensive because of the high salaries paid in that industry. Indeed, the opposite is true, Mr. Speaker, as you will have recognized.
Perhaps, Mr. Speaker, the Minister could take few minutes to respond to the statements I have made and use the occasion to outline government policy vis-a-vis shoe imports and indicate the current state of affairs. More particularly, will she explain to us if she is aware of the policy of the Government toward the quota system which, as I understand it, is supposed to expire some time in 1986? Perhaps the Minister could respond to that.

speakerposition: Deputy Chair of Committees of the Whole
speechtext: I would bring to the attention of the House that once the Minister speaks, the debate will be terminated. Are there any questions or comments on the speech of the Hon. Member?

Mr. Speaker, I just want to ask one question of the Hon. Member in connection with protecting shoe manufacturers in Canada. We have a shoe manufacturing firm in the city of Calgary which employs anywhere from 20 to maybe 200 people. They make cowboy boots, which are in great demand in the West. However, they get no protection whatsoever from tariffs. In addition to that, when they bring inspectors in from the United States to check their highly complicated equipment, there is a hassle every time and they are held up for seven or eight hours. I think this is information that the Minister should have.

November 26, 1984

My question to the Hon. Member is this: Was he aware that the western shoe manufacturers get no protection whatsoever?

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take a few moments to make some comments with respect to Bill C-9. As my friend, the Hon. Member for Bow River (Mr. Taylor), mentioned, there are a number of areas on which I believe the Department would do well to focus so as to see if we cannot clean up some old legislation which is of nuisance value. I draw the attention of the House, and in particular of the Minister, to the practice of placing an exercise tax on farm wagons.
Historically, agricultural equipment has been brought into Canada without tariff. At the turn of the century and into the 1920s the farm wagon was used for a dray to pick up the mail and the goods for the garage and the store. Farm wagons were driven by horses around the villages and hamlets across Canada to deliver the dray to various points of business. Because the wagon was used for those purposes, it was classified as a commercial vehicle in customs and tariff regulations.
At the present time, farmers will import forage harvesters from another country. Often the undercarriage of that harvester is of a light weight and the farmer wishes to have a heavier weight carrier. If the new carrier is imported separately, it enters the country unattached to the forage harvester and is called a wagon. At that point the customs and excise tariff must apply. That really related back to a 1920s regulation which no longer makes sense. There are a number of people across the country in agricultural communities who would be pleased if the Department would study this inequity.
I would also like to bring to the attention of the House the matter of bees and beehives. The production of nitrogen-fixing clovers in the country and the importing of woodstock for beehives is a very important aspect of the food producing industry. Its capacity in terms of both the leaf-cutter bees and the honey bees is important as an industry in all parts of Canada. It is simply not good enough to say that the product is made in Canada and therefore there should be a tariff on it. If the product is not of sufficiently quality for the people who use it in the industry to be satisfied with it, there should be some exemption from the tariff. That product is made in Canada, but every year representatives of the Canadian bee industry say that they want to use hives that are made in another country. I believe that we should be allowed to do that until the Canadian industry produces a quality product that is satisfactory to Canadians. I have no doubt that Canadians can make that product to satisfactory standards. Giving a monopolistic licence to market a product without there being any
November 26, 1984

competition or any regard to the quality of the product is detrimental.
This will be the first time in history that anyone has ever corrected the Hon. Member for Bow River, Mr. Speaker. However, he made reference to cowboy boots. There is no such thing as cowboy boots except that which you give to your four-year-old children at Christmastime. However, there are western boots. There are manufacturers of western boots in Canada. They make western boots for adults but not for children. When stocking a rack with boots you must have several pairs of each size. As there are Canadian manufacturers, you must buy from them, but they do not supply children's western boots. If you wish to get your young child cowboy boots, as my friend from Bow River calls them, you will find that they are not in ample supply on the shelves because there are no Canadian manufacturers of them and we can import only a small number. I believe that that ought to be reviewed within the regulatory process. Suppliers ought not to be restricted in the number of children's boots they can import simply because the larger sizes are available.
The final point I wanted to make concerns grain drying equipment. Farm implement dealers everywhere are bringing in grain drying equipment. They bring it in as models and set up fans, screens and floorings from separate components parts. Because the fans and the screens could be used for another purpose, when they are sold the dealers must pay the full brunt of the tax. I am simply saying that as long as there is an end user certificate for the use to which they will be put, I do not believe it matters whether grain drying equipment is sold as one component or in parts.
Those who are in the grain drying import business will say that there is a problem with selling component parts. It is often not necessary to bring in the full equipment because component parts can be added to existing facilities. It should not be mandatory to buy a full set of equipment when it is satisfactory to add component parts to the existing facilities.
My comments were intended simply to point out that there are some inequities in the customs and excise tariffs which can be improved upon in the regulatory process. I would encourage the Minister to review those and, if possible, to make the necessary changes.

Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest to the Hon. Member's comments about western boots in particular, as well as concerns raised by others about the boot industry. As an experienced outdoorsman in western Canada, does he know that a similar situation exists with firearms? This is in terms of duties that are paid on firearms that theoretically are available in Canada. Mr. Speaker, I can only attest to the fact that I am in fact aware of and in agreement with the observations that were made by the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis).

Mr. Speaker, it is interesting that a number of the Bills which are coming before the House in its early stages permit us to set out some of our philosophical approaches to such issues as taxation, which we dealt with this morning, and trade, with which we are dealing now. Since the Minister has launched consideration of Bill C-9 by giving us an outline of her approach to trade and the approach that the Government is taking toward trade, I want to comment on that approach and offer some counterpoising of a different approach which our Party intends to put forward.
In my opinion, the Minister was speaking very much in a framework which saw the need for us to move toward more free trade. It was in a framework that saw that movement taking place in a multilateral context, with GATT playing a

November 26, 1984
Customs Act
very important role in the process, with safeguards being maintained for Canadian industry as this process is developed.
Of course, there are a number of other variants on this commitment to greater free trade. Some people are talking very much in terms of establishing our free trade with the United States unilaterally rather than with all the countries throughout the world. Again, there are variations within that approach. Some people talk in terms of sectoral approaches to such free trade, while others talk about an approach that moves across the board.
When we consider international trade in the 1980s, our Party questions the strategy of developing greater free trade. When one looks at the evidence, the reality is a movement throughout the world toward managed trade.
This type of trade operates at two levels. First, there is managed trade at the level of governments themselves. We have seen a movement by governments, both in developed countries and less developed countries, whereby a great deal of special financing is available for exports. They have many agencies operating in an attempt to promote trade expansion and penetrate new markets. In short, we see an attempt by governments to build for themselves new areas of comparative advantage in the international economy which will provide their respective countries with jobs and growth prospects in the future. This is not only evident in western European countries but it is evident also in the United States where, despite the free trade rhetoric of the Reagan regime, there have been a great many moves in recent months that threaten our economy and other trading economies throughout the world as a result of new forms of restrictionism within the United States. The most recent example is some provisions in the steel industry which have established particular labelling requirements for steel exporters to the United States. This has the effect of making our capacity to export to that economy a great deal more difficult.
I think most Members are aware that in addition to the Government's efforts to manage trade, we must recognize the effort on the part of large-scale firms to manage and organize trade internationally. In this respect we can talk of two kinds of development. First, there is the effort on the part of large corporations to set up for themselves an international system of sourcing abroad. At present, large international corporations use subsidiaries in different parts of the world to supply particular components to parent companies in the United States or western Europe. For instance, estimates of the situation in the United States indicate that close to 60 per cent of U.S. manufacturing trade takes place in the internal framework of the corporations themselves. This means that the prices that are established in that trade are often quite arbitrary and questionable.
In addition to this effort to set up international corporate structures to organize trade throughout the world, we see an increasing effort on the part of corporations to attempt to develop trade strategies based on a careful working through of new product developments and heavy expenditure on research and development within those product areas. They attempt
then to allocate to particular subsidiaries throughout the world responsibility for that product once it is developed by the company.
We see a good many companies here in Canada which now have world mandates for particular products which have been developed through research in their parent companies. In these and other ways we have a movement toward managed trade in the corporate sector as well as in government legislation and regulation. I think for us to respond in the world as it is changing by being a good boy scout, by talking about freer trade when nobody else is practising it, by suggesting that, left to the market, somehow the trade that we as a country need to grow will just emerge, represents an incredible exercise in naivety. It represents an abdication of responsibility as a Parliament to the millions of workers in Canada who could be affected by this. It represents irresponsibility with regard to the thousands upon thousands of small business people who could find their hopes and opportunities eliminated.
I agree with my colleague from Saskatchewan who made the case for free trade that it is something that could benefit many of us. But free trade is not on the agenda of the world today. We can look all over the world, we can look at Southeast Asia, western Europe and, the United States. Freer trade is not the direction in which countries are moving. Managed trade is the direction. For us as a small nation in this difficult and open environment, faced as we are with our own severe economic problems, simply to back off and say we will leave it to free exchange throughout the world, is not only naive but incredibly irresponsible.
It is particularly irresponsible to talk about establishing this kind of free exchange system with the United States. It is above all within the United States that the corporate sector is moving effectively, and because it makes sense for them, in the direction of more and more manged trade. We would find ourselves like the poor fly caught up in a spider's web. We would be at the outer extremities of a system of trade that has been built on the U.S. market itself. We would find company after company that presently has subsidiaries here looking to rationalize operations continentally and leaving us without any capacity to safeguard jobs and to protect our potential for growth for the future.
We will be bringing before this House tomorrow a case where precisely this kind of thing has happened. I am speaking of a takeover by an American company of the operations of a segment of Westinghouse responsible for small appliance production. Black and Decker has taken over these operations and is now in the process of rationalizing production. At the moment it can only rationalize production within Canada because we still have some trade restrictions. FIRA still exists and can still operate, but the result is that an operation is being shut down in Barrie, Ontario, which presently employs 600 people who are represented by a good Conservative Member of Parliament.
November 26, 1984
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The Hon. Member is incorrect. He referred to Westinghouse when he meant General Electric.

The Hon. Member for Simcoe South (Mr. Stewart) is correct. It is a General Electric subsidiary rather than a Westinghouse subsidiary. I apologize.
The point is that a company has been taken over by another parent company, which in turn is attempting now to rationalize its world-wide operations, and in the process of doing so is threatening the jobs of 600 workers within a community in Ontario.
We see the chance of this kind of development in the future becoming more and more prevalent if we move in the direction of free trade with the United States. Some people are talking about an alternative which they call sectoral free trade. This moves in the same direction but will do so industry by industry. We have had some experience with that in the case of the automotive sector. We have seen that such movements can be beneficial to the Canadian economy, but only if safeguards are established that defend the industry by committing subsidiaries here in Canada to a specific level of Canadian content production in what they sell here. In the case of the auto pact, for instance, companies have committed themselves to 60 per cent Canadian content as an equivalent for each dollar's worth of sale of their vehicles here in Canada. We feel that that principle of Canadian content has to be there within any movement to sectoral free trade with the United States, or indeed with anybody else.
We believe strongly, and we have had it on good faith from negotiators from the United States, that they are not prepared to initiate and include safeguard arrangements in any of the sectoral free trade movements which they are presently talking about.
We would put ourselves in a situation where we would not be able to protect ourselves as we have been able to do in the auto industry. Rather than moving in this direction of freer trade, Mr. Speaker, we think the world as it is requires us to talk about what we in this Party call fairer trade, an attempt to establish, through the activity of government in close consultation with the corporate sector, with trade unions, and with communities across the country, a system of safeguards that will permit various key sectors of our industrial economy to expand effectively, to initiate more research and development and to use that research and development to penetrate new export markets, not on the basis of special arrangements with those markets but on the basis of competitive quality products which can be produced by Canadian workers and communities. We think particularly of sectors that are crucial to our future, for instance, the automobile sector.
It is important for us to accept the principle of the recent task force on the automotive industry of establishing Canadian content rules, not just with the United States and American companies as we presently have, but with Japan and Japanese
Customs Act
companies. As I have stressed previously in the House, this industry now cuts across the country. It is not just an Ontario and Quebec industry. There are automotive investments in provinces such as British Columbia and on the other coast in Nova Scotia. If we move in the direction of serious efforts to build in Canadian content laws as the task force report suggested, we will have before us 30,000 to 50,000 new jobs which will benefit the entire country, not only central Canada.
Also I want to make it clear that when we talk about fairer trade, we are not talking about always building in more restrictions. We are also talking about seeing to it that our restrictions deal fairly with the different trading partners with which we are involved. For instance, at the moment we apply quotas in areas such as textiles and clothing to poor developing countries when those countries themselves are often not the threat. If we look at the case of textiles and clothing, we see that many of the threatening imports these days come not from Sri Lanka, against which we have quotas, not from Malaysia, against which we have quotas, not from India, against which we have quotas, but from the United States, against which we do not have quotas because frankly we are frightened to do so.
Our argument is that in establishing a system of fairer trade, it is important that we treat our trading partners equitably and that we approach them in an even-handed manner. We should stop making the Third World and poorer countries pay the price for competition in some of our poorer, more difficult industries. This competition is in fact coming much more from the United States and other parts of the world which are a good deal better off.
We lay before the House today an approach to trade strategy which emphasizes fairness rather than the freeing of the economy. If we adopt that approach, we will be safeguarding jobs for the future and much more effectively building the capacity to expand our economy through exports and through growth in the future.

Mr. Speaker, I have a comment or two and then a question for the Hon. Member for Essex-Windsor (Mr. Langdon). I disagree that the world is not moving toward free trade. If the Hon. Member as a member of these parliamentary committees will be able to visit Hong Kong, Korea, parts of the Philippines and Malaysia, he will find that the future lies with free trade if we get on the ball and capture our fair share. The whole sense of his speech was that he was fearful of free trade. We should look at Canada with its magnificent resources, our population, the fact that we have a higher standard of education than anywhere in the world, a stable political environment and an effective economic infrastructure. We have huge multinationals. Our banks are huge multinationals. There are four or five big oil companies in Canada, with 700 oil and gas companies mostly based out of Calgary. A good number of them operate on the international sphere. They are incredibly productive and valuable.
Why does my friend fear for their ability to operate? Why does he want to have protections which will hurt us? Indeed, a closed trading pattern will hurt our country more than any

other country in the world. We trade even more than the Japanese for our wealth and welfare. Why does he want protections? Would he not think that Austria's trading practice vis-a-vis Germany is a good example to follow? That country has opened itself up, and its productive citizens have found thousands of niches within which they can fit and send products to Germany. As a result, its national wealth has risen enormously. Why does my friend appear to be fearful?

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the question. It is a very good one. However, I suggest to the Hon. Member that his assumption is wrong. I certainly do not have a sense of fearfulness about the capacity of our country, our companies and our communities to compete. I am concerned about our country sending out our companies on which workers depend into the international market-place unassisted, unaided or unsupported by our Government and our trading strategy.
I have had a certain amount of experience with Southeast Asia. Recently I visited South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong. I assure the Hon. Member, as indeed I am sure he is aware, that South Koreans do not let their companies go into the international market-place unsupported. We should ask why it is that Hyundai has succeeded in penetrating the market for automobiles in Canada in such a spectacular fashion. There has never been a more spectacular entry into the auto sector than in the case of Hyundai. Hyundai is strongly supported by the Korean Government. There is a major effort on the part of the Koreans to promote such exports and at the same time a very strong effort to see to it that Hyundai cars which are exported have a far higher Korean content than anything we require.
In the case of Hyundai and the Pony cars which come to Canada, over 93 per cent of cars produced in South Korea are produced with Korean content; 93 per cent of the value added in those vehicles is Korean. If we are to realize our tremendous capacity, the way to do it is not to leave our companies on their own. It is not to pretend that the world is some kind of easy picnic in the international market-place these days. It is to be out there supporting our companies, working closely with them and developing a strategy to build effectively upon our capacity.
This is what we are talking about when we talk about fair trade. This is why we make a distinction between that and free trade, which I think is a recipe for leaving our companies unprotected in what is a terribly difficult world. Some of them will still succeed, some of them will still do well. However, many of them could do much better if we worked aggressively with them and we recognized how naive it is to pretend that the world is not moving toward a managed trade system rather than a free trade system.

The Hon. Member opposite referred to the automobile industry. Would he agree with the action taken by the government in the early 1970s? When the oil price was rising, our government stepped in and said that we would not be subject to any blackmail from the Arab community, and we subsidized it. The effect of that was to send signals to Canadians to continue to buy big cars and to manufacturers to continue to build them. In the meantime, Japan, Germany and many other countries with governments that faced reality used their top brains to create more efficient and lighter cars. The reason they are whipping us in the market is that our industry was misled by the government and led down the garden path. It happened because of that action taken by the government.
I suppose I am asking the Hon. Member to consider that as being a case which argues for government being very circumspect in its decision-making and that if it is to help industry, it be very careful in the way it does so. That was a clear example of a government decision that mortally injured the industry. Tens of thousands of people were put on the unemployment rolls because of the decision that was made back in the early 1970s.

Mr. Speaker, having read the Hon. Member's speech earlier, I have heard that argument before. In fact, Mr. Speaker, the direction in which the auto industry moved in the early seventies was a function not of Canadian Government policy but of what was happening in the United States. Unfortunately, the great overwhelming majority of research and development in that industry is now concentrated in the United States and responds very much to changing incentives and regulations imposed by the U.S. Government.
My own view is that the U.S. Government, by forcing its auto companies to move in the direction of more fuel-efficient cars, saved that industry for the 1980s. Without those government regulations, the U.S. auto industry would not have moved fast enough. It would not be in a position to compete in the way that it is finally beginning to compete internationally.

Mr. Speaker, I have a brief question for the Hon. Member. Who really speaks for the NDP on this issue? Is it the Hon. Member for Kamloops-Shuswap (Mr. Riis), who argued in favour of liberalized trade to help the developing nations? Is it the Hon. Member for Prince Albert (Mr. Hovdebo), who also argued in favour of liberalization by showing figures to the House indicating that western Canadian agriculturalists were subsidizing inefficient industries in eastern Canada? Is it those two gentlemen from the West, or is it my antediluvian friend from the East, who continues to argue in favour of protective trade or managed trade or trade of whatever name he wishes to give it?

speechtext:
Mr. Pat Nowlan (Annapolis Valley-Hants) moves that Bill C-201, an Act respecting the official designation of "Nova Scotia", be read the second time and referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and Legal Affairs.
He said: Mr. Speaker, in the true tradition of private Members' hour, there should not be much debate on this Bill which is so patently fair, progressive and highly principled on the face of it. I certainly do not wish to take the entire time of the House between five o'clock and six o'clock, but I do want to describe briefly my private Member's Bill which I brought before the House on another occasion several years ago. After that, I remained quiet about the Bill because of the sensitivity of the bilingual question that seems to come up whenever I raise this Bill.
As far as I am concerned, if there ever was a reason for a private Member's Bill, there is a reason for Bill C-201, which is comprised of only one paragraph. It is a private Member's Bill which deals with a matter of public interest to the people

November 26, 1984
Designation of Nova Scotia
of Nova Scotia involving no more and no less than the proper use of a proper noun in the proper context.
The proper noun we are dealing with, of course, is the name "Nova Scotia", which is Latin and, in my humble submission, therefore is not translatable to either English or French. If, under the BNA Act and under its original Charter, Nova Scotia was called "New Scotland", then in our day of bilingualism, the translation for that would be "Nouvelle Ecosse". However, the fact of the matter is that the name is Nova Scotia. It is a proper name that comes from a grant made by King James I to William Alexander in 1621. This was before Canada was ever even conceived of in terms of any constitutional arrangement. There were Indians present, and I shall return to that.
There are many names in Canada, historic names which reflect our history and heritage, which are not and should not be translated. I must say that this Bill germinated when I was a new Member of Parliament. This is why I am glad to raise it again in a new Parliament which consists of so many new Members. I was a Member of a new Parliament back in 1966 when in this far corner of the Chamber a very eminent Canadian, who happened at the time to be an independent Member and the ex-mayor of Trois-Rivieres, Mr. J. S. Mongrain, rose in his place every time an anglophone mentioned the words "Three Rivers". He would bring the proceedings to a halt. I suppose there were times in that new day of bilingualism that anglophone Members were irritated at the question of privilege or point d'ordre being raised on the use of the name Three Rivers.
Then there was the interesting situation of another eminent federal Member at the time, who has had some eminence in Quebec politics since that time, Gilles Gregoire. He represented part of the riding which now encompasses Sept-Iles. I worked in a place which was known as Seven Islands when the Iron Ore Company was only a dream. Before the railway was built along the Moisie River there was a fishing village with a population of 1,500 which was known as Seven Islands. However, quite properly attention was drawn to the fact that under the Charter of Seven Islands the proper noun for Seven Islands was Sept-Iles. Those points were made and they were accepted.
I submit that my case is even stronger than the cases which I have mentioned. I am not talking about a translation; I am talking about the use of a proper noun in the proper context. If there are Members, Nova Scotians or Canadians, who feel more comfortable using other appellations for my Province, then let them use them. The Bill does not restrict anyone or make it illegal to use any other name. Obviously I know the name that a majority of the people in my Province are familiar with, that is the name of la Nouvelle Ecosse. If in their social context and in their dialogues they feel more comfortable using Nouvelle Ecosse, so be it. Depending on the results of this debate today, the point of truth, frankly, Mr. Speaker, may become perhaps a problem between you and me. I believe
it is high time that a name which has existed for three and one-half centuries, which is neither English nor French but is Latin, should be the proper noun which is used for my Province. I will have to consider my position and how obstreperous I will become if this Bill does not find favour with the House.
I will not quote all of the Latin of the King James Charter which was given to Sir William Alexander, although it is beautiful stuff. There are pages and pages of Latin which relate to Nova Scotia. That is the first part of my case.
One can say, "What is in a name?" I will cite some interesting and ridiculous situations with respect to what is in a name.
When I was first in this House, Mr. Speaker, one of your eminent predecessors was Mr. Speaker Lamoureux. He was a very gracious Speaker and obviously a great predecessor of yours. However, on the English side we did not call him "Mr. Lover". Nor did we call Gilles Lamontagne, the former Minister of Defence, "Mr. Mountain". We did not call and do not call Madam Sauve, "Madam Saviour", although she was a Speaker who certainly saved the decorum of the House from completely breaking down from time to time. We did not do that because it would make a mockery of the sincerity and seriousness of bilingualism for us to become too fervent in deciding that every word should be translated, especially proper nouns. It is grammatically incorrect to translate proper nouns into another language, be it from English to French or from French to English.
In the present Cabinet we have Roch La Salle. Are we going to call him "Roch the Room"? We also have John Wise. Are we to call him "Jean Le Sage"? That obviously points to the absurdity of the matter. We could do it with Andree Champagne, who is a lovely lady. I have not had the pleasure of formally meeting her too often, but I will certainly call her by her name and not "Andree Field". That would be a mockery and an insult to her.
All I am asking is for fairness in using the proper nouns in the proper context. The Bill is very simple. Paragraph 1 reads:
This Act may be cited as The Official Designation of Nova Scotia Act.
That is simple. It does not pose a problem. The second paragraph reads:
In every place where the words "Nova Scotia" appear in any Act, regulation, statutory instrument, report, contract, lease, licence or other document the proper designation of such name in both official languages is and shall be "Nova Scotia".
I will not get into the situation of wanting rewritten all the laws which must be translated. I simply want to ensure from this day forward that we will not translate proper nouns when those words are not translatable.
I know Members in this House are versed in history and I do not want to take much of the time of the House, but I found it interesting, when I researched this matter, that the very name of Canada is an Indian name. We do not translate that. Ottawa is a very interesting Indian name. It perhaps typifies what we do in this city, but it is not translatable. Quebec,
November 26, 1984

Ontario, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan are other well-known proper nouns which are not English or French, but Indian and, therefore, not translatable. In terms of the name of Canada, there is some conflict in history which obviously occurred when Jacques Cartier sailed up the St. Lawrence and picked up some guides along the way. Those guides were probably Iroquois. They referred to the villages along the St. Lawrence as Kanata or Canadia. In effect, the translation from Iroquois was that this was the place of cabins or lodges. The translation of that into French from Iroquois became "Canada". That is fine. We do not want to destroy the heritage of 1867. We have the Constitution Act, the flag, the national anthem, and a Supreme Court which can stop things in Ottawa. We have done things to emancipate our national identity and to develop our heritage. Surely we do not want to turn back the clock in this context.
In terms of other names, we could take the great Province of Ontario. "Ontario" comes from two Iroquois words. I will not try to translate them, but in effect Ontario means "beautiful lake". Quebec is Algonquin, and means "where the river narrows". The other side of that is Detroit, but I will not get into that. Saskatchewan comes from the Cree language and means "rapid current". Manitoba again comes from the Cree language and means "the strait of the Manito" or "the strait of the spirit". The most interesting example is that of the capital city itself, Ottawa. I believe "Ottawa" comes from the Algonquin language and means the place to barter or the place to trade. I must say that the Indians knew years ago, before anyone ever thought of this place-which used to be called Bytown-that it would be the place where we came to trade or to barter.
These names are not translatable and they should not be translatable.
I would like to delve into history for a moment to amplify what I said about Sept-Iles and Trois-Rivieres. The history of this is perhaps the evolution of Canada and of Quebec. There was a Bill introduced in 1915 in the Statutes of the Province of Quebec which referred to the City of Three Rivers. Then, because of many happenings and obviously the emancipation and the movement of the English and the French, in 1925 there was an amendment under the Statutes of the Province of Quebec which amended the English name "Three Rivers", and in effect said that the inhabitants and ratepayers of the City of Three Rivers would henceforth be known as inhabitants of the "City of Trois-Rivieres". It was because of that history, Mr. Speaker, and I believe, quite properly, that Mr. Mongrain, as an independent Member of Parliament-and I sat back there against the back wall-whenever Three Rivers was mentioned by any speaker, would stand and in a very proper way draw to the attention of the House that this was not the proper name.
I will quote from an excerpt of Hansard of March 25, 1966, at page 3195. With regard to the estimates of the Department of Transport-that was when we had full supply in the House-Mr. Mongrain said this, among other things:
Designation of Nova Scotia
For the last 15 years, Mr. Chairman, the municipal councils. Chambers of Commerce, both junior and senior, and the school boards of my home town and riding have been writing to the various federal departments to underline the fact that the name of my home city is Trois-Rivieres. This is true even in spite of the English version because the city is incorporated under the name of Trois-Rivieres. A proper name is not translated and it is a grammatical error to translate a proper name. For instance, the name of our Speaker is Mr. Lamoureux but I would not speak of him in English as Mr. Lover. Mr. Batten is an English name but I would not call him. Mr. Planchette if 1 were speaking French to him. We have a minister by the name of Mr. Winters but 1 would not call him Mr. Hiver if I were speaking to him in French. The name of my riding is Trois-Rivieres and I do not know how many hundred times we have to emphasize that fact.
Mr. Mongrain continues, in another part of his discourse, saying this:
But the pride we show in wanting our city's name to be expressed in our mother tongue should not be held against us.
This is the point I want to make. I take great pride in Nova Scotia even though I am basically of Irish heritage. We have a fine Scottish heritage. There was a grand fellow by the name of William Alexander. We have the celebration of the meeting of the clans. We have the tartan and the kilt. We take pride in our heritage. The fact that I am today pushing for the use of the proper name when referring to my Province is because of the respect I hold for my province, and for no other reason. It is a principle, as far as I am concerned, Mr. Speaker. I only ask for the same fairness given to me as was given Mr. Mongrain with "Trois-Rivieres" today and in the future.
I will not go into the whole evolution of history today, Mr. Speaker, because I would like other Hon. Members to contribute to the debate. But I repeat that I believe we make a mockery of bilingualism by translating names which have the strength of history behind them without the popular acceptance of the people who believe in their heritage. My home town, Mr. Speaker, is a place called Wolfville. It happens to be the seat of Acadia University. The whole history of the area comes from the Acadians. Every Nova Scotian and every constituent in my constituency talks about Grandpre. We do not talk about the "Big Meadow". We do not call Wolfville "La Ville du Loup". My mother was born in a place called Canard. I have heard about canards being used in canard a l'orange, but I have never known the area surrounding my mother's farm being known as "The duck land", Mr. Speaker. We do not call Whitehorse "Cheval Blanc". We do not call Mont Joli "Mount Jolly". We do not call the riding of the former Prime Minister "Royal Mountain". And, Mr. Speaker, we do not call Baie Comeau "Como Bay". I do not think we should.
I say to you, Mr. Speaker, that in fairness, equity and in history, this Bill goes right back to the 1621 Charter. I have a photostat of the BNA Act which is in English because we had evolved from Latin to English. We were not bilingual then. I would like an Hon. Member or the Table Officers to point out to me where there has been the legal move to use the name "Nouvelle Ecosse" or "New Scotland" in referring to the Province of Nova Scotia. I can tell you, Mr. Speaker, that by the proclamation of Queen Victoria which brought us into nationhood-and Nova Scotia, of course, was one of the four founding provinces-the Provinces of Canada, Nova Scotia

November 26, 1984
Designation of Nova Scotia
and New Brunswick are united into one dominion under the name of "Canada". I suggest and submit, Mr. Speaker, that the 1867 proclamation brought us into being. Even in the Constitution Act of 1982, or whenever it was, which in effect reaffirmed the BN A Act and made the Constitution more modern, there is not a section in the statute which gets close to what they did with Trois Rivieres-Three Rivers officially to designate the change from Nova Scotia to any other name.
It is for that reason, Mr. Speaker, that 1 am happy to have had the chance to speak for these few minutes before the House. I hope I have not over-stressed the point, but I do believe it is time we considered this matter seriously. One can say, "What is in a name?" But long ago an Hon. Member of this House, the Hon. Member from Shawinigan, stood in this House during a private Member's hour and wanted the name of Trans Canada Air Lines changed to that of Air Canada. There was quite a debate and the Bill went through. That was many years ago when that Hon. Member was relatively new. 1 do not expect the same hallelujah if my Bill goes through today. That was one of the first Bills to, in effect, make a name almost "alingual", but I do not even have to face that. The proper name of my Province is Nova Scotia; it is not New Scotland, it is not Nouvelle Ecosse.
I ask the consideration of the House to reflect on my remarks. Hopefully, the reflection will conclude before six o'clock so that this Bill can be properly referred to the Standing Committee on Justice and Legal Affairs. I believe that if we do get it that far, it is high time that Nova Scotians, including its Premier, addressed this problem.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to be taking part in the debate on this Bill.
In fact, I was reading about past debates on the subject in some old volumes of Hansard, and I cannot help wondering why another attempt is being made to bring this legislation before the House today. I must say that I wish it were a quarter to six or six o'clock or whenever we are going to vote on this Bill this evening, because it will be very interesting to see how our Quebec colleagues in the Progressive Conservative Party vote on this particular Bill.
I intend to be very brief to give these Hon. Members an opportunity to take part in the debate and show us how they intend to vote.
Mr. Speaker, the history of the Acadians in Canada is very important, although at times many Canadians have trouble remembering that particular history.
The Hon. Member who is sponsoring the Bill referred to the Acadians earlier, but I think his remarks need some elaboration. We should remember what happened in 1755, remember the deportation of the Acadians and their arrival in large numbers in Louisiana and related events.
Today, we should also remember the day when the Conservative Government of our country closed the consulate in
Louisiana, which I think was a slap in the face of the people of Louisiana, especially Acadians. Today, this Bill is once more before the House.
Mr. Speaker, I must say that as a Francophone outside Quebec, I am very reluctant to support this kind of legislation. That is why I fully intend to vote against the Bill, and I also wish to take advantage of this opportunity to urge my francophone colleagues here in the House of Commons to do the same, especially our colleagues from Quebec on the other side of the House. I would urge them, first, to rise in the House and let us know what they think of the proposed legislation and give us their views, and second, before the House adjourns this evening, to vote against the Bill.
We are told that the reason for presenting this Bill is that in 1621, the province was given the name "Nova Scotia". That may be so. In fact it must be so, because the Hon. Member said so. However, Mr. Speaker, in 1621 legal texts were probably all written in Latin. I therefore fail to understand why it is so important for us to remember this particular incident today. It is quite possible that at the time, a lot of other things were given Latin names as well, but today, these have been translated into other languages. Prince Edward Island is called "l'lle-du-Prince-Edouard" in French, and when I go to the Maritimes next year, I want to be able to go to Nouveau-Brunswick, if that is what I want to call that province, and to "la Nouvelle-Ecosse", if that is how I want to call that province. If the Hon. Member wants to go on calling his province Nova Scotia, he is welcome to do so. I think we should keep the province's French name, the way it has been translated for centuries. It is correct, and I think especially in the present context, it is a way of showing the Acadians of our country some small recognition, and we certainly owe them at least that.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as this is my maiden speech in the House as Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State, I would like to start by congratulating you on your recent appointment.
I would first like to provide a few explanations on the origin, the functions and the responsibilities of the Committee responsible for geographical designations in Canada.
The first organization in charge of controlling geographical names in Canada was created by Order in Council in 1897 under the name of Geography Commission of Canada. In 1948, this Commission became the Canadian Commission of Geographical Names, and in 1961, it received its present designation of Canadian Standing Committee on Geographical Names.
The Committee is made up of seven representatives from Federal Departments and one representative from each province in Canada appointed at the provincial level. The
November 26, 1984

Committee rules on all nomenclature issues involving Canada. Toponyms within the provinces become decisions of the Committee upon a ruling by the provinces involved. The Committee is assisted in its work by four advisory committees in charge of names, linguistic policy and research. There are about 300,000 officially approved names in Canada.
The Official Languages Act and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms determine the policy of the Federal Government as far as the policy of the Canadian Standing Committee on Geographical Names is concerned. The Committee must therefore see to it that when members of both official language groups use federal maps they are served with consistency and fairness. Toponomy is also one of the essential elements which help create our national image as a country where both official language groups share a common heritage, each one designating major geographical entities in its own language.
To better meet the needs of Canadians of both official language groups, names which appear on federal maps must first of all match those used in legal documents, that is the names adopted by the provincial authorities within their own province and by federal authorities within the regions under their jurisdiction.
The purpose of a federal approach would be to determine which are the place names of geographical entities that are of national interest in both official languages. These names should be considered part of the collective ownership of the Canadian people, or in other words of its national heritage.
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian Permanent Committee on Geographical Names has been guided for a long time by the principle that, excluding entities under the jurisdiction of the Canadian government such as Indian reserves, national parks and Canadian Forces bases, geographical names are a provincial matter. The names of the provinces themselves, of course, are a different problem. According to the Department of Justice, the name of a province is that used in the Constitutional Act under which that province entered Confederation. In the case of Nova Scotia, that act of course is the British North America Act, a statute originally passed in English only. The Department of Justice is currently preparing an official French version of that act. However, all previous French versions of that act referred to "Nouvelle-Ecosse". There is therefore no reason to believe that the latest text will be any different.
Be that as it may, since constitutional documents are involved, the Canadian Government could not make changes without having them approved by the provinces. In the same way, provinces could not change their names without requesting the Canadian Government approval. We may therefore conclude in my view that this is an area of joint jurisdiction, where the lead should preferably come from the Legislative Assembly of the province concerned.
With respect to geographical names, past and present practice has been and is one of the main elements to be considered. Now, the use of the name "Nouvelle-Ecosse" in
Designation of Nova Scotia
treaties, in historical works, on maps and in geographical documents dates back to the 18th century. It has been in continuous use since then and remains current usage not only among French-speaking Nova-Scotians and Canadians generally, but throughout the French-speaking nations. That was the name used in the 1713 Treaty of Utrecht, under which France finally yielded Nova Scotia to Britain. It must be remembered that, first settled by France under the name of "Acadie", Nova Scotia was under French rule from 1667 to 1710. On the other hand, even if the name "Nova Scotia" is indeed of Latin origin, it has long since ceased to be perceived by people in that province and Canadians in general as anything but the English name of a very predominantly English province.
Mr. Speaker, this may be but a technicality, but one should not overlooked the fact that if Nova Scotia's official name were to be changed, changes would have to be made not only to federal statutes but also to all official documents, maps, and so on, bearing the name of that province. On the other hand, such a change, at a point in time where over-all Canadian attitude to bilingualism is entering a phase of greater tolerance and more general acceptance, might very well stress relations between those two linguistic groups and polarize their mutual positions. The name "Nouvelle-Ecosse" is part of the cultural heritage of Nova-Scotians and all Canadians.
